A 2023 study shows a link between climate change and increased turbulence.

source_title: Exposing The Flaw In Our Phone System
description: This video explores the vulnerabilities of SS7, a signaling protocol used in 2G/3G telecommunications. Researchers demonstrated the interception of phone calls and text messages, including two-factor authentication codes, remotely. They also showed how to track a target's location by using signal triangulation from cell towers. The cost for accessing SS7 was shown to be ~$13,000 per month, highlighting the financial incentives and risks to network security. The video also includes an interview with Princess Latifa, who was tracked and returned to Dubai. Finally, the video discusses the need for stronger security protocols as more networks migrate to 5G.

source_title: I built a QR code with my bare hands to see how it works
description: QR codes, ubiquitous in modern life, surprisingly have a history rooted in early efforts to digitize information. Their checkerboard pattern dates back to early telegraphy, using dots and dashes (Morse code) to transmit electrical pulses. Later, the need for efficient data storage in industries like retail led to the invention of barcodes and, subsequently, the QR code. The COVID-19 pandemic further accelerated QR code adoption for contactless transactions and health information management. The inherent structure of QR codes, inspired by the Go board game, and the use of Reed-Solomon error correction coding enable robust data transmission, even with significant damage. Future improvements may focus on increased data capacity and enhanced security.

source_title: People said this experiment was impossible, so I tried it - Thermite Part 1
description: The Goldschmidt thermite reaction, discovered in 1895, is an exothermic redox reaction between a metal oxide (e.g., Cr₂O₃, Fe₂O₃) and a reducing agent (Al). Experiments using 300g thermite mixtures generated temperatures exceeding 2000°C. A novel approach using thermally resistant glass allowed direct observation of the reaction. The reaction's pulsating nature is attributed to trapped air and varying reactant ratios. Modern applications leverage the reaction's controlled heat for metal joining and data destruction via Curie temperature effects.

source_title: We Might Find Alien Life In 2229 Days
description: A NASA Europa Clipper mission, launching October 2024, will investigate Jupiter's moon Europa for signs of life. Europa's surface lacks impact craters, suggesting recent resurfacing. A subsurface ocean, possibly 100km deep, is hypothesized. Jupiter's powerful magnetic field (20,000x Earth's) and Io's volcanic sulfur dioxide emissions create intense radiation belts. Tidal flexing from Jupiter's gravity generates heat, potentially maintaining liquid water despite Europa's -160°C surface temperature. Data from the Galileo probe and spectroscopic analysis support the presence of a subsurface ocean. The Europa Clipper's instruments will analyze plumes for chemical composition, searching for evidence of life.

source_title: The Closest We’ve Come to a Theory of Everything
description: This video explores the Principle of Least Action, a fundamental concept in physics. It traces the historical development of the principle, from early work by Hero of Alexandria and Fermat to the contributions of Bernoulli, Euler, and Lagrange. The video uses examples from classical mechanics, optics, and calculus to illustrate the principle and its applications, culminating in Hamilton’s formulation of the principle, and its use in solving complex problems in physics. The video concludes with a discussion of the mathematical rigor of the principle, and its broader implications for understanding the universe.

source_title: On These Questions, Smarter People Do Worse
description: This video uses a field experiment to examine how political ideology and numeracy affect the interpretation of data. Researchers presented participants with data on a fictitious skin cream trial, and then a similar data set on gun control, manipulating the framing of the data. Results revealed that individuals with higher numeracy scores were more likely to interpret data correctly. However, political affiliation strongly influenced interpretation, particularly amongst the least numerate, demonstrating the impact of ideology on rational decision-making. A further investigation into the role of science curiosity in mitigating this effect is suggested.

source_title: The Most Important Material Ever Made
description: This video explores the history and science of glass, integrating materials science, chemistry, and archaeology. Naturally occurring glass, like obsidian, formed billions of years ago via meteorite impacts, lightning strikes, and volcanic eruptions. Humans began using obsidian ~1.2 million years ago; however, controlled glassmaking began only ~5600 years ago. Common soda-lime glass (SiO2, Na2CO3, CaO) is amorphous, lacks a crystalline structure, and is brittle; its production requires high temperatures (1700°C). Modern Gorilla Glass uses ion exchange (K+ for Na+) to increase compressive strength, improving scratch and drop resistance. The development of transparent glass revolutionized optics and our understanding of the universe.

source_title: What Actually Happened To Amelia Earhart?
description: This video uses the disappearance of Amelia Earhart to explore physics, specifically radio wave propagation. Earhart's Lockheed Electra, modified to maximize fuel capacity, lacked sufficient radio range for her equatorial route across the Pacific. Dead reckoning was insufficient; celestial navigation, requiring sun, moon, and star sightings, was also unreliable. The video demonstrates how radio waves, being transverse, can be directionally detected using loop antennas to locate signal nulls. Earhart's smaller antenna and the Itasca's use of the same antenna for sending and receiving at high frequencies likely contributed to the communication failure. A larger, more robust radio system would have likely prevented this catastrophe.

source_title: Why can't you see a rainbow looking at the Sun?
description: Rainbows result from light’s interaction with water droplets. Sunlight refracts and reflects within droplets, creating a cone of light. The maximum scattering angle for this reflected light determines the rainbow's arc, varying with light frequency (color), explaining the rainbow’s colors and 42° angle. Polarization filters can make rainbows disappear by blocking the rainbow's polarized light. Supernumerary rainbows result from interference, requiring tiny droplets; glories, also from interference, form around the observer's shadow. C.T.R. Wilson's cloud chamber research, inspired by glories, led to a Nobel Prize.

source_title: 34 Years Of Strandbeest Evolution
description: This video explores the artistic and engineering principles behind Strandbeests, wind-powered kinetic sculptures created by Theo Jansen. The design's evolution involved overcoming six major challenges, including structural integrity and smooth locomotion, which were addressed through computational simulations and iterative design. The project draws upon principles of engineering, computer science, and art, showcasing a unique approach to kinetic sculpture design. The video also reflects on the artist’s motivations and the broader implications of the work in relation to environmental change and human legacy.

source_title: This Musical Instrument Took Eons To Make
description: The Luray Caverns in western Virginia contain a unique musical instrument, a lithophone, constructed using stalactites. Discovered in 1878, this extensive cave system (26 hectares) inspired mathematician Leland Sprinkle to create the organ in 1957 using electro-mechanical mallets, steel bolts, and electric guitar pickups. Stalactites' resonant frequencies depend on size and shape, with larger ones producing lower notes and growth rates varying with water flow (16cm³ per 120 years). The organ's design utilizes the natural reverb of the cavern, creating a unique sonic experience. Radio interference posed a challenge, resolved by using the ferromagnetic properties of steel bolts within the stalactites for signal detection.

source_title: The Man Who Took LSD and Changed The World
description: This video details the invention of Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR). Using light microscopy and gel electrophoresis, the method amplifies DNA sequences by utilizing heat-stable DNA polymerase from *Thermus aquaticus*, enabling rapid diagnostics and forensic applications. A key figure, Kary Mullis, is highlighted for his role in conceiving PCR, although the video also credits the collaborative efforts of his colleagues at Cetus Corporation, along with their contributions towards the method's refinement and eventual success. The video further discusses the implications of automation and its impact on scientific discovery.

source_title: Why Don’t Railroads Need Expansion Joints?
description: This video details the thermite welding process used to join railway tracks. The process, discovered by Hans Goldschmidt, involves an exothermic reaction between aluminum powder and metal oxide, producing molten metal for welding. The experiment demonstrates the eight steps involved, highlighting the importance of precise rail alignment (both vertical and horizontal) and preheating to avoid cracking due to thermal expansion and contraction. Microscopic analysis reveals distinct zones in the weld: the weld seam and heat-affected zones. The heat-affected zones exhibit a finer grain structure and reduced hardness, representing the weakest points in the welded rail, as demonstrated by a strength test using a bending press. The video concludes by explaining how mechanical stress from sleepers and ballast counteracts thermal expansion/contraction in railways.

source_title: Why is MIT making robot insects?
description: Miniature robots, inspired by insects, are being developed for diverse applications. Researchers leverage biomimicry and micro-robotics to design robots capable of flight and aquatic locomotion, overcoming challenges of surface tension and scaling laws. Innovative actuation methods, including combustion engines and soft polymers, are explored to achieve high-frequency wing flapping and efficient movement. The design and functionality of these robots are discussed alongside the scientific principles involved.

source_title: Why Super Glue Is Perfect For Gluing Skin
description:
This video details the accidental discovery of superglue's adhesive properties by Harry Coover in 1942 while researching clear plastics for gunsights.
The key component, ethyl cyanoacrylate, rapidly polymerizes upon contact with negatively charged ions in moisture.
A chemical engineer explains that this reactivity stems from the electron deficiency of the carbon double bond, adjacent to a nitrile and ester group.
The resulting polymer chains are strong under tension, but brittle under shear stress. This brittleness is mitigated with longer polymer chains, leading to applications in medicine and potentially, closed-loop recyclable plastics.

source_title: What if you just keep zooming in?
description: Using electron microscopes, scientists have overcome the challenge of visualizing individual atoms, a feat once considered impossible. Early attempts were limited by the inherent properties of electromagnetic lenses, which cause spherical aberration. The 1936 Scherzer theorem established this limitation, but a later workaround using hexapole, octopole, and decapole magnets, allowed researchers to achieve resolutions down to 0.13 nm, enabling clear atomic imaging. This breakthrough, awarded the 2020 Kavli Prize, revolutionized materials science.

source_title: The Most Useful Thing AI Has Ever Done
description: AlphaFold2, a DeepMind AI, predicts protein structures with unprecedented accuracy. Developed using deep neural networks and trained on a massive dataset of known structures and evolutionary information, it achieves >90% accuracy in CASP14. This surpasses prior methods, like X-ray crystallography, in speed and cost. AlphaFold2's applications span diverse fields, including drug design, disease research, and material science. Its transformative potential underscores the power of AI in accelerating scientific discovery.

source_title: The Google Interview Question Everyone Gets Wrong
description: This video explores the classic Google interview question: "You're shrunk to the size of a nickel and dropped into a blender; the blades start in 60 seconds. What do you do?" Layperson responses are compared to expert opinions incorporating physics (drag, forces, scaling), biology (muscle structure, respiration), and computer science (simulation). A physics-based model, accounting for drag and scale, demonstrates the possibility of escape via jumping; however, physiological limitations at miniature scale (respiration, blood pressure) are also considered. The video concludes that such brain-teasers assess neither technical skills nor problem-solving abilities.

source_title: e to the pi i, a nontraditional take (old version)
description: This video uses intuitive visualizations to explain Euler's formula, e^(πi) = -1. It leverages concepts from calculus (infinite series, exponential functions), complex analysis (complex numbers, imaginary unit 'i'), and linear algebra (transformations of vectors) to demonstrate that e^x can be understood as a transformation converting addition into multiplication in a natural way. This framework extends to complex numbers, clarifying why Euler's formula holds true.

source_title: Euler's Formula Poem
description: This video uses visual representations to explain Euler's identity (e<sup>πi</sup> = -1). It leverages concepts from mathematics (complex numbers, exponentiation) to illustrate how the identity arises from the geometric interpretation of complex number multiplication in the complex plane. Visualizations show how multiplication by e<sup>πi</sup> corresponds to a rotation of π radians (180 degrees) about the origin. The video’s intuitive approach bridges abstract mathematical concepts with concrete visual demonstrations.

source_title: Euler's Formula and Graph Duality
description: This video offers an elegant proof of Euler's characteristic formula (V-E+F=2) for planar graphs using graph theory. It leverages concepts of cycles, spanning trees, and dual graphs. The proof employs a visual method, illustrating how a spanning tree in a graph relates to its dual, leading to the derivation of Euler's formula. The video also showcases the abstract nature of graphs using diverse examples, including social networks and word relationships.

source_title: What does it feel like to invent math?
description: This video explores the concept of infinite sums in mathematics, using the example of 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/8..., which converges to 1. The video then introduces the concept of a distance function in geometry and explores how to define distance between rational numbers. A novel distance function, the 2-adic metric, is presented, which is shift invariant and leads to the discovery of p-adic numbers, a new class of numbers in number theory. The video concludes by contrasting the invention and discovery aspects of mathematics.

source_title: How to count to 1000 on two hands
description: This video demonstrates a method for counting to 1023 using only ten fingers, assigning powers of 2 to each finger. The process leverages binary representation and arithmetic summation. Cognitive psychology is highlighted, showing pattern recognition enabling faster calculation with practice. This system extends to counting significantly higher numbers using toes, reaching 1,048,575.

source_title: Music And Measure Theory
description: This video explores the connection between music theory and measure theory in mathematics. It uses frequency ratios of musical notes to illustrate the concept of rational and irrational numbers. The analysis reveals that the pleasantness of a musical interval correlates with the simplicity of its frequency ratio, expressed as a fraction with a small denominator. Measure theory is introduced, applying Lebesgue measure to quantify the ‘mass’ of rational numbers within the real numbers. The video demonstrates that despite the density of rational numbers, their Lebesgue measure is zero, highlighting the counter-intuitive aspects of measure theory.

source_title: Fractal charm: Space filling curves
description: This video explores space-filling curves, illustrating Hilbert's curve and the Peano curve through iterative construction. It extends the concept to triangle-filling curves, including the "Flow Snake," defined by Bill Gosper. The video also demonstrates how well-known fractals, such as the Koch Snowflake, can be described using iterative methods and a "seed" pattern, modifying the angle to generate different space-filling curves. The video employs geometric and fractal analysis to showcase visual representations and iterative algorithms.

source_title: The Brachistochrone, with Steven Strogatz
description: This video explores the brachistochrone problem, using a conversation between the narrator and mathematician Steven Strogatz. The problem, to find the curve of quickest descent, is framed historically, referencing Johann Bernoulli's 17th-century solution and Galileo Galilei's earlier, less accurate attempt. Modern mathematician Mark Levi's geometric insight, connecting the problem to Snell's Law of refraction in physics, is presented, alongside a proof employing principles of mechanics and energy conservation. The video concludes with a challenge to find a new solution using intuitive reasoning in t-θ space.

source_title: Snell's law proof using springs
description: This video derives Snell's Law (sin(θ₁)/vₐᵢᵣ = sin(θ₂)/vʷₐₜₑᵣ) using Fermat's principle of least time and a mechanical analogy. It leverages optics and classical mechanics, employing geometric reasoning and a thought experiment with springs to avoid calculus-based derivations. The analogy highlights the minimization of potential energy in a system, demonstrating a broader principle of nature's tendency toward equilibrium.

source_title: Triangle of Power
description: This video explores mathematical notation, specifically focusing on the inconsistencies in representing exponentiation, roots, and logarithms. The presenter argues that current notation hinders learning by failing to visually represent the inherent relationships between these inverse operations. A proposed solution introduces the “Triangle of Power,” a visual model where numbers representing these operations are placed at the vertices of a triangle, enabling a more intuitive and symmetrical understanding of their interconnections. This aids in visualization and clarifies the underlying mathematical principles, potentially improving mathematical pedagogy and reducing common student errors. The video also briefly touches upon the application of a similar concept to parallel resistance calculations in physics.

source_title: Essence of linear algebra preview
description: This video introduces a series on linear algebra, emphasizing the importance of geometric intuition alongside numerical computations. It highlights the applications of linear algebra across diverse fields, including computer science, physics, and engineering, and demonstrates the need for both numerical proficiency (matrix multiplication, determinants, eigenvectors) and geometric understanding for effective problem-solving. The series will cover vectors, linear transformations, and determinants, promoting a balanced approach to understanding linear algebra concepts.

source_title: Vectors | Chapter 1, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video explains vectors from three perspectives: physics, computer science, and mathematics. Physicists view vectors as arrows in space, defined by length and direction. Computer scientists represent vectors as ordered lists of numbers. Mathematicians generalize, defining vectors as anything with sensible addition and scalar multiplication. The video demonstrates vector addition and scalar multiplication graphically and numerically, emphasizing their fundamental role in linear algebra. Finally, it introduces scalars as numbers used to scale vectors.

source_title: Linear combinations, span, and basis vectors | Chapter 2, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain vector coordinates in two and three dimensions. It introduces the concept of basis vectors (î, ĵ) and scalar multiplication to define vector coordinates as scaled basis vectors, illustrated graphically. The span of a set of vectors is defined as the set of all linear combinations. The video contrasts linearly independent and linearly dependent vectors, showing that the span of two linearly independent vectors covers the entire 2D plane, and the span of three linearly independent vectors covers 3D space. Finally, a technical definition of a basis of a vector space is provided.

source_title: Linear transformations and matrices | Chapter 3, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses geometrical visualization to explain linear transformations in two-dimensional linear algebra. It defines linear transformations as functions that map vectors to vectors while keeping grid lines parallel and evenly spaced, with the origin fixed. The video demonstrates matrix-vector multiplication as a method for numerically describing these transformations, showing that a 2x2 matrix completely encodes a 2D linear transformation via the coordinates where basis vectors land. Specific examples using rotation and shear transformations are provided.

source_title: Matrix multiplication as composition | Chapter 4, Essence of linear algebra
description: Linear transformations, functions mapping vectors to vectors, are visualized as distortions of space preserving parallel grid lines and the origin. A transformation is fully defined by its action on basis vectors. Matrix-vector multiplication computes the transformed vector; matrix multiplication composes transformations. Matrix multiplication is associative, meaning order of operations is irrelevant to the final transformation.

source_title: Three-dimensional linear transformations | Chapter 5, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video explains linear transformations in 2D and 3D using matrices. 2D transformations are visualized on a grid, then extended to 3D using a 3x3 matrix representing the transformation on 3 basis vectors (î,ĵ,k̂). The resulting matrix concisely describes the 3D transformation, applicable to computer graphics and robotics. Matrix multiplication of two 3x3 matrices is shown to represent the composition of two transformations.

source_title: The determinant | Chapter 6, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain determinants. A 2D linear transformation’s determinant is the factor by which it scales area. A negative determinant indicates orientation inversion (flipping). In 3D, the determinant scales volume; negative values represent orientation inversion, visualized using the right-hand rule. The determinant of a matrix product equals the product of the determinants.

source_title: Inverse matrices, column space and null space | Chapter 7, Essence of linear algebra
description: Linear algebra concepts, including inverse matrices, column space, rank, and null space, are explained using linear transformations. A matrix's determinant being zero means its transformation squishes space to a lower dimension, precluding an inverse. Rank describes the dimensionality of the output space (column space), while the null space encompasses vectors mapping to zero. Full-rank matrices maintain dimensionality, ensuring an inverse exists. These geometric interpretations provide intuition for solving linear equations.

source_title: Nonsquare matrices as transformations between dimensions | Chapter 8, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain the geometric interpretation of matrices. It demonstrates transformations between 2D and 3D vector spaces using 2x2 and 3x3 matrices, then expands to non-square matrices (3x2 and 2x3), illustrating how these represent transformations between different dimensional spaces. The concept of a matrix's column space is introduced and visualized, showing how the dimensions of the input and output spaces relate to matrix rank. Finally, 1D transformations are explored, connecting to dot product concepts.

source_title: Dot products and duality | Chapter 9, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video explores linear algebra, specifically dot products, from both numerical and geometrical perspectives. Numerically, the dot product is calculated by pairing corresponding coordinates of two vectors, multiplying the pairs, and summing the results. Geometrically, it represents the length of the projection of one vector onto the line spanned by the other, scaled by the length of the second vector. The sign of the dot product indicates whether the vectors generally point in similar or opposing directions. The concept of duality in mathematics is introduced to explain the connection between these two perspectives. Linear transformations from multi-dimensional spaces to a single dimension are analyzed, revealing a correspondence between 1x2 matrices and 2D vectors. A visual test based on evenly spaced dots is presented to assess linearity.

source_title: Cross products in the light of linear transformations | Chapter 11, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain the 3D cross product. It leverages concepts of determinants and duality to demonstrate that the cross product of vectors v and w is the dual vector of a specific linear transformation from 3D space to the number line. Geometrically, this transformation computes the signed volume of the parallelepiped defined by the input vector and v, w. The computational approach involves computing a determinant with symbolic basis vectors; the geometric interpretation relies on vector projection. Both methods yield the same dual vector, illustrating the connection between computational and geometric aspects of the cross product.

source_title: Cross products | Chapter 10, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video provides an introductory overview of the cross product of two vectors. It leverages linear algebra, specifically determinants, to calculate the cross product's magnitude as the area of the parallelogram formed by the two input vectors. The sign of the result reflects the vectors' orientation, determined by the right-hand rule. The cross product itself is a vector perpendicular to the plane spanned by the inputs, with a length equal to the parallelogram area. A deeper exploration is promised in a subsequent video.

source_title: Change of basis | Chapter 13, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain coordinate systems. A vector’s coordinates are scalars that scale basis vectors (e.g., î,ĵ) whose tip-to-tail sum defines the vector. Different basis vectors yield different coordinates for the same vector, illustrating how coordinate systems are constructs, not intrinsic to space. Matrix-vector multiplication translates between coordinate systems via a change-of-basis matrix and its inverse. A transformation matrix in one system is translated to another via A⁻¹MA, where A represents basis vectors.

source_title: Eigenvectors and eigenvalues | Chapter 14, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain eigenvectors and eigenvalues. Eigenvectors, when transformed by a matrix, remain on their own span. The scaling factor is the eigenvalue. Finding eigenvalues requires computing the determinant of a modified matrix (A-λI), solving for λ when this determinant is zero. An eigenbasis uses eigenvectors as a basis; if present, the transformation matrix becomes diagonal, simplifying computations. Not all matrices possess eigenbases.

source_title: Abstract vector spaces | Chapter 16, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video explores the fundamental nature of vectors in linear algebra. It contrasts the representation of vectors as arrows in space with their representation as lists of numbers, highlighting that core linear algebra concepts like determinants and eigenvectors are independent of the chosen coordinate system. The video extends these ideas to function spaces, illustrating vector addition and scaling for functions as analogies to vector operations. The concept of linearity is defined formally in terms of additivity and scaling, and exemplified by the derivative operator in calculus, represented as an infinite matrix. Finally, the video emphasizes the unifying role of axioms in defining vector spaces and their applications across diverse mathematical settings.

source_title: Who cares about topology?   (Old version)
description: This video explores the inscribed square problem in topology, demonstrating a solution for inscribed rectangles. A 3D function maps pairs of points on a closed loop to their midpoint and distance, creating a surface. The function's continuity and behavior when point pairs coincide are analyzed, proving the existence of an inscribed rectangle using topological principles. The associated surface's properties and the Möbius strip are discussed.

source_title: 3blue1brown channel trailer
description: This video showcases animated math explanations. Linear algebra concepts, such as eigenvectors and determinants, are visualized using 2D and 3D animations. The presenter emphasizes the artistic and intuitive aspects of mathematics, aiming to make abstract concepts more accessible and engaging through visual representations. The video also highlights the use of visual aids to improve the learning and understanding of mathematical principles.

source_title: Binary, Hanoi and Sierpinski, part 1
description: This video uses the Tower of Hanoi puzzle to illustrate the relationship between recursion in computer science and binary counting in mathematics. The presenter explains how to solve the puzzle by associating the binary counting rhythm with a specific pattern of disk movements. The connection highlights the self-similarity inherent in both processes, offering an efficient solution to the puzzle. The video also includes a brief overview of binary number systems and their place-value structure.

source_title: Binary, Hanoi, and Sierpinski, part 2
description: This video explores the constrained Towers of Hanoi puzzle, demonstrating its solution through ternary counting. The video connects this to the structure of Sierpinski's triangle, visualized as a graph where nodes represent puzzle configurations and edges represent moves. The algorithm's efficiency is highlighted, illustrating concepts from computer science and graph theory, alongside mathematical principles of recursion and base-3 number systems. The resulting graph structure mirrors Sierpinski’s triangle, showcasing fractal geometry.

source_title: But what is the Riemann zeta function? Visualizing analytic continuation
description: This video uses complex analysis to visualize the Riemann zeta function ζ(s), defined as the sum from n=1 to ∞ of 1/nˢ for Re(s) > 1. The visualization maps complex inputs s to complex outputs ζ(s). For Re(s)>1, the sum converges. Analytic continuation uniquely extends ζ(s) to the complex plane, revealing “trivial zeros” at negative even integers and non-trivial zeros in the “critical strip” (Re(s)=1/2), whose distribution is related to prime numbers and the unsolved Riemann Hypothesis.

source_title: Tattoos on Math
description: This video explores the pedagogical implications of teaching trigonometric functions. It uses the example of a trigonometric function tattoo to illustrate the arbitrary nature of naming conventions in mathematics. The video uses geometric representations on the unit circle to visually explain trigonometric functions and their relationships, contrasting their inherent mathematical properties with the historical reasons for their naming conventions. The discussion also touches upon the evolution of trigonometric calculations from pre-computer era tables to modern computational methods.

source_title: Fractals are typically not self-similar
description:
Fractals, coined by Benoit Mandelbrot, are characterized by non-integer dimensions. The video employs computer algorithms to generate self-similar fractals like the Sierpinski triangle (≈1.585-dimensional) and the Von Koch snowflake (≈1.262-dimensional).
A box-counting method, leveraging logarithmic scaling, empirically determines fractal dimension for any shape, revealing the coastline of Britain as ≈1.21-dimensional and showcasing how fractal dimension quantifies roughness across scales. The video further contrasts this with other notions of dimension from linear algebra.

source_title: Euler's formula with introductory group theory
description: This video explores group theory, focusing on the symmetries of mathematical objects, and their relationship to exponentiation. It uses visual representations of group actions on squares and circles, and illustrates how these actions correspond to addition and multiplication of real and complex numbers. The video employs visual and mathematical methods to demonstrate that the exponential function maps the additive group of complex numbers to the multiplicative group, highlighting the significance of the constant *e* and its properties within this context. The video also discusses applications of group theory in cryptography, molecular symmetry, and other mathematical fields.

source_title: The essence of calculus
description: This video uses geometrical methods to explain core Calculus concepts. It demonstrates how the area of a circle can be derived by summing the areas of concentric rings, approximating each as a rectangle. This introduces integrals and derivatives as inverse operations, visualized as the area under a curve and its slope, respectively. The Fundamental Theorem of Calculus is illustrated by showing how the derivative of the area under a curve equals the curve's function.

source_title: The paradox of the derivative | Chapter 2, Essence of calculus
description: This video explains derivatives in calculus, using a moving car as a central example. The instantaneous rate of change is shown to be an oxymoron, as change requires multiple points in time. Derivatives are then defined as the slope of a tangent line to a curve, approximated by the ratio of small changes in distance and time (ds/dt). The limit as the change in time (dt) approaches zero is shown, resolving the paradox by providing a best constant approximation for rate of change at a single point. The derivative of t³ is derived as 3t², illustrating calculus principles via visualization and algebraic methods.

source_title: Derivative formulas through geometry | Chapter 3, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses geometric interpretations to explain derivatives. Calculus is applied to model real-world phenomena, such as velocity and population growth, using polynomials, trigonometric, and exponential functions. The power rule for derivatives of xⁿ is derived, and the derivative of sin(θ) is shown to be cos(θ) via geometric reasoning.

source_title: Visualizing the chain rule and product rule | Chapter 4, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses geometrical intuition to explain the chain rule and other rules of calculus. It leverages concepts from differential calculus, specifically derivatives, and applies them to functions combined via summation, multiplication and composition. Visual aids help explain the meaning of these operations and their derivatives, using area as a key analogy. The video also introduces mnemonic devices for easier recall.

source_title: What's so special about Euler's number e? | Chapter 5, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses calculus to explain why *e* is the most important exponential. It uses population growth as an illustrative example, applying derivatives to show how the rate of change in population mass is proportional to the population size. This proportionality constant is shown to be the natural log of the base for any exponential function, and that only *e* results in a proportionality constant of 1, because the derivative of *e<sup>t</sup>* is *e<sup>t</sup>*. The chain rule is introduced to explain derivatives of more complex exponential functions. The video further explores the application of exponential functions in diverse scientific contexts, including population dynamics, thermodynamics and finance.

source_title: Implicit differentiation, what's going on here? | Chapter 6, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses geometric and calculus concepts to explain implicit differentiation. It applies the Pythagorean theorem to a circle and calculates the slope of a tangent line at a given point using implicit differentiation. The method is then extended to related rates problems using a ladder example, where the Pythagorean theorem, again, helps establish the relationship between variables. The derivative of the natural logarithm is derived using the implicit differentiation technique.

source_title: Limits, L'Hôpital's rule, and epsilon delta definitions | Chapter 7, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses calculus to explain limits. It defines derivatives formally and introduces the epsilon-delta definition of limits. Additionally, it demonstrates L'Hôpital's rule for computing limits of indeterminate forms, clarifying its application and historical context within real analysis. The video utilizes visual aids and examples to build intuitive understanding alongside rigorous mathematical definitions.

source_title: Integration and the fundamental theorem of calculus | Chapter 8, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses the example of a car's motion to explain integrals in calculus. It shows how the area under a velocity vs. time curve represents the distance traveled. Approximating the area with rectangles, and then taking the limit as the width of the rectangles goes to zero, leads to the concept of the definite integral. The fundamental theorem of calculus is introduced, connecting integration and differentiation. Negative velocity implies negative distance, showing that integrals measure signed area.

source_title: What does area have to do with slope? | Chapter 9, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses calculus to explain the concept of averaging a continuous variable. It leverages graphical representations of sine waves and their integrals to illustrate the relationship between integrals and derivatives, showing how the average value of a function over an interval can be expressed as the integral of the function divided by the interval's length. The video also connects this concept to the more intuitive notion of averaging a finite set of numbers, using the analogy of approximating an integral as a sum of areas of rectangles. Additionally, it explores the application of this concept in various fields like physics and engineering.

source_title: Higher order derivatives | Chapter 10, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses calculus to explain the concept of higher-order derivatives. It demonstrates how the first derivative represents slope, while the second derivative represents the rate of change of the slope (concavity), illustrated with graphs and analogies to motion (velocity and acceleration). The third derivative, "jerk," describes changes in acceleration. Taylor series are introduced as a method for function approximation using higher-order derivatives.

source_title: Taylor series | Chapter 11, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses Taylor series to approximate functions. It leverages calculus (derivatives, integrals) and physics (pendulum motion) to illustrate the concept. The approximation improves with additional terms, but convergence is limited by the radius of convergence. The Taylor expansion of eˣ converges everywhere; that of ln(x) near x=1 does not.

source_title: Pi hiding in prime regularities
description: This video explores the relationship between prime numbers, complex numbers, and pi. It uses visual representations of lattice points within circles of varying radii on the complex plane to derive a formula for pi. The derivation involves number theory concepts like prime factorization, and calculus techniques such as infinite sums and integration, to demonstrate a surprising connection between seemingly unrelated mathematical concepts. The video also introduces the concept of Gaussian integers and multiplicative functions.

source_title: All possible pythagorean triples, visualized
description:
Pythagorean triples, integer solutions to a²+b²=c², are explored using geometric and algebraic methods.
The video visualizes these triples on a Cartesian plane and introduces complex numbers.
Squaring complex numbers with integer coordinates generates additional triples, forming parabolic arcs on the plane.
A formula is presented, and the relation between lattice points and Pythagorean triples is discussed, highlighting the connection between number theory and geometry.

source_title: But how does bitcoin actually work?
description: This video uses a simplified ledger system to explain the fundamental concepts underlying cryptocurrencies. It covers cryptography, specifically digital signatures and cryptographic hash functions. A communal ledger is introduced, highlighting the need for trust. The video then explains the use of public and private keys for secure transactions. The concept of "Proof of Work," using SHA256 hash functions, is introduced as a means of achieving decentralized consensus in the blockchain. Finally, the video discusses block rewards and transaction fees in Bitcoin, concluding with a comparison to Visa's transaction processing speed.

source_title: How secure is 256 bit security?
description: This video explores the vast scale of the number 2<sup>256</sup>, illustrating its magnitude by relating it to computational power. It uses the example of cryptographic hash functions, where finding a specific 256-bit string requires a brute-force search. The video leverages computer science concepts such as SHA256 and parallel processing with GPUs, alongside estimations of Google’s server capacity and the number of stars in the Milky Way, to provide a relatable visualization of exponential growth and the infeasibility of certain computations. Bitcoin mining's use of Application-Specific Integrated Circuits (ASICs) is highlighted for its efficiency.

source_title: Hilbert's Curve: Is infinite math useful?
description: Space-filling curves map 1D to 2D space. The video explores Hilbert curves, useful in translating images to sound. A 256x256 pixel image requires an order 8 pseudo-Hilbert curve for efficient mapping, ensuring consistent spatial relationships even with higher resolutions. The concept of continuity in mapping functions is demonstrated, contrasting Hilbert and snake curves. Finally, the video links this to the broader mathematical concept of utilizing infinite theoretical constructs to understand finite applications.

source_title: Thinking outside the 10-dimensional box
description: This video explores the relationship between analytic and geometric viewpoints in mathematics, particularly in higher dimensions. It uses linear algebra (determinants), geometry (circles, spheres), and number theory (Pythagorean triples, prime numbers) to illustrate this relationship. A novel 'real estate' analogy is presented to visualize higher dimensional spaces, revealing counterintuitive properties of spheres in high dimensions. The video concludes by demonstrating that the proportion of an inner sphere's volume within a bounding box decreases exponentially with increasing dimensions.

source_title: Some light quantum mechanics (with minutephysics)
description: This video uses classical wave mechanics to build intuition for quantum mechanics. Electromagnetic radiation, described by Maxwell's equations, is shown as oscillating electric and magnetic fields. Superposition, amplitudes, and phases are introduced within this classical context. The quantization of energy in photons is contrasted with classical wave energy, with the square of the amplitude determining energy in classical physics and probability in quantum mechanics. Experimental results with polarizing filters are presented, demonstrating this probability. The video concludes by illustrating how wave functions in quantum mechanics are analogous to classical wave superpositions, employing complex numbers to represent amplitudes and phases.

source_title: But what is a neural network? | Deep learning chapter 1
description: Neural networks, inspired by biological neural structures, are explained using a 2-layer perceptron model. Image recognition is achieved via 784 input neurons (28x28 pixels), 16 neurons per hidden layer, and 10 output neurons (digits 0-9). Each connection has a weight, and each neuron a bias. The sigmoid function transforms weighted sums into 0-1 activations. The model's 13,002 parameters are tuned via a learning process (detailed in a subsequent video). Linear algebra is essential for understanding this process. ReLU activation functions are introduced as more efficient alternatives to sigmoid.

source_title: Gradient descent, how neural networks learn | DL2
description: This video explains how neural networks learn using the MNIST database of handwritten digits. A network with 784 input neurons, two hidden layers of 16 neurons each, and 10 output neurons (one per digit) is used as an example. The network’s weights and biases (approx. 13,000 parameters) are initialized randomly and adjusted via gradient descent to minimize a cost function. This cost function is the sum of squared differences between the network's output and the desired output for each digit. The gradient of the cost function is used to determine the direction and magnitude of adjustments made to the parameters, aiming for a local minimum of the cost function. The video also shows that even with randomly-labeled data, the network still exhibits high accuracy, raising questions about the nature of generalization in deep learning. Further resources are provided.

source_title: Backpropagation, step-by-step | DL3
description: Backpropagation, a core neural network training algorithm, is analyzed. An intuitive walkthrough is provided, avoiding explicit formulas. Gradient descent, a key optimization method, is visually explained using cost surfaces. A cost function, based on squared differences between network output and desired output, is calculated for individual and averaged across multiple training examples. The negative gradient of this cost function, a vector in high-dimensional space, dictates adjustments to network weights and biases. The magnitude of each gradient component reflects sensitivity to weight/bias changes. Computational efficiency is enhanced by stochastic gradient descent, using mini-batches of training data, rather than the entire dataset for each gradient descent step. A loose analogy is drawn with Hebbian theory in neuroscience. Python code implementing backpropagation is shown.

source_title: Backpropagation calculus | DL4
description: This video uses calculus to explain backpropagation in neural networks. A simple network is modeled, where the cost function is the squared difference between the network's output and a desired value. Partial derivatives of the cost function with respect to weights and biases are calculated using the chain rule, revealing the sensitivity of the cost to small changes in network parameters. The approach extends to more complex networks by iteratively applying the chain rule and summing over multiple paths. This gradient calculation enables iterative minimization of the cost function via gradient descent.

source_title: The hardest problem on the hardest test
description: This video uses the Putnam mathematical competition to illustrate problem-solving strategies. The median score on this undergraduate exam is low, highlighting the difficulty of the problems, despite their elegant solutions. The presenter analyzes a challenging 3D probability problem by simplifying it to 2D, demonstrating problem reduction as a key strategy. The 2D solution involves geometric probability and average arc length calculations. Finally, a surface integral approach to the 3D problem is suggested, connecting the concepts of probability and multivariable calculus.

source_title: Q&A #2 + Net Neutrality Nuance
description: This video announces a Q&A session and discusses computer engineering principles, specifically the functionality of a computer's components as explained by Ben Eater. A conversation with Ben Eater about net neutrality follows, focusing on potential tradeoffs and the decentralized possibilities offered by technologies such as blockchain.

source_title: Why this puzzle is impossible
description: This video explores the mathematical properties of planar graphs and their application to the “utilities puzzle.” Participants attempted to solve the puzzle on both a 2D plane and a topologically equivalent torus (a mug). The planar graph version proved impossible via Euler’s characteristic formula (V-E+F=2), whereas the toroidal version was solvable using the mug’s handle. The experiment highlighted graph theory, topology, and problem-solving methodologies.

source_title: But what is the Fourier Transform?  A visual introduction.
description: This video uses animated visualizations to introduce the Fourier Transform, a mathematical concept with applications across diverse fields. It decomposes sound into constituent frequencies, illustrating the principle of superposition. The video further explores connections to the uncertainty principle, Riemann zeta function, differential equations, and concepts from physics, particularly the center of mass. It uses an “almost Fourier transform” method, and concludes by introducing the full mathematical formulation.

source_title: The more general uncertainty principle, regarding Fourier transforms
description: This video uses the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle from quantum mechanics as a springboard to discuss the Fourier transform. The Fourier transform is a mathematical tool that decomposes functions of time into component frequencies, or functions of space into spatial frequencies. This is analogous to the quantum mechanical uncertainty principle where a particle's position and momentum are inversely related; precise knowledge of one implies less precise knowledge of the other. Doppler radar is also discussed as an example, where precise knowledge of distance via time delay is inversely related to precision of velocity, via Doppler frequency shift. This highlights an underlying uncertainty principle not limited to quantum mechanics.

source_title: Why is pi here?  And why is it squared?  A geometric answer to the Basel problem
description: This video uses a visual analogy to demonstrate a geometrical proof of the Basel problem, an infinite sum of inverse squares. It employs concepts from calculus (infinite series), number theory (integers and squares), and physics (inverse square law of light intensity), representing the summands as the apparent brightness of lighthouses. The visualization relies on geometrical principles (similar triangles, Pythagorean theorem, inscribed angle theorem) in 2D and 3D space to show that the sum converges to π²/6. A GeoGebra applet is provided for interactive exploration.

source_title: How pi was almost 6.283185...
description: This video explores mathematical history and the conventions surrounding the circle constant. It contrasts the use of π (as the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter) with τ (ratio of circumference to radius), referencing Hartl's "Tau Manifesto" and Palais' "Pi is Wrong!". Historical analysis of Euler's 1748 calculus text reveals his use of π to represent both the semicircumference-to-radius and quarter-circle-to-radius ratios, depending on the problem. The video concludes by highlighting the context-dependent nature of mathematical constants and the importance of problem-solving over rigid adherence to established conventions.

source_title: Winding numbers and domain coloring
description: This video describes a 2D equation solver algorithm. The algorithm uses a recursive bisection method, leveraging the intermediate value theorem. Visualizations utilize color mapping to represent the magnitude and direction of 2D function outputs. The approach relates to topological concepts, particularly Stokes' theorem, and its efficiency scales with the perimeter, not the area, of the search space. The video also explores limitations of the initial algorithm and introduces a refined version.

source_title: The Wallis product for pi, proved geometrically
description: This video presents a novel proof of Wallis' product formula for π using circle geometry and complex polynomials. The proof leverages two key lemmas related to the product of distances from an observer to points evenly spaced on the unit circle. The first lemma establishes a constant distance product when the observer is halfway between points. The second shows the distance product equals the number of initial points when the observer is positioned at one of them. These lemmas, combined with dominated convergence, yield the Wallis product and a product formula for sine. Formal details are available in a supplementary blog post.

source_title: The other way to visualize derivatives | Chapter 12, Essence of calculus
description: This video uses graphical intuition to explain calculus concepts. It contrasts the standard derivative visual (slope of a graph) with a transformational view (input-output mapping), showing how the latter generalizes more easily to multivariable calculus, complex analysis, and differential geometry. The transformational view is applied to analyze an infinite fraction, revealing two fixed points: the golden ratio (φ ≈ 1.618) and its negative reciprocal (-1/φ ≈ -0.618). Iterative calculations show φ as a stable fixed point and -1/φ as an unstable one, depending on whether the magnitude of the derivative at the fixed point is less than or greater than 1. The video concludes that the transformational perspective, while sometimes less intuitive than graphs, offers benefits for understanding advanced calculus topics.

source_title: Divergence and curl:  The language of Maxwell's equations, fluid flow, and more
description: This video uses fluid flow to illustrate the mathematical concepts of divergence and curl. Divergence, calculated using the dot product, quantifies the rate of fluid generation or dissipation at a point. Curl, computed via the cross product, measures local fluid rotation. These concepts extend beyond fluid dynamics, finding application in electromagnetism (Maxwell's equations) and ecological modeling (predator-prey dynamics), representing change in multivariable systems using phase flow visualizations. The Jacobian matrix provides a complete analysis of such systems.

source_title: Other math channels you'd enjoy
description: This video celebrates the 3Blue1Brown YouTube channel's 1 million subscribers. It features three other math creators: Think Twice (visually-driven geometric animations), LeiosOS (community-focused algorithmic exploration using Verlet & Euler methods, Huffman encoding, Chan's algorithm, and data compression), and Welch Labs (long-form series on math and science, including workbooks). Infinity Plus One blog, with playful content on relativity and other advanced topics, is also highlighted.

source_title: Why slicing a cone gives an ellipse (beautiful proof)
description: This video uses geometry to demonstrate three equivalent definitions of an ellipse: stretching a circle, a thumbtack-and-string construction, and slicing a cone. The demonstration includes a proof that the conic section created by slicing a cone possesses the constant focal sum property defining the ellipse drawn by the string method. The eccentricity of an ellipse is introduced and calculated using the ratio of the distance between foci to the major axis length. Finally, the video explores Dandelin spheres and their application in proving the equivalence of ellipse definitions.

source_title: Q&A with Grant Sanderson (3blue1brown)
description: This video is a Q&A session featuring Grant Sanderson, a mathematician and educator. He discusses his career path, including work at Khan Academy and current YouTube endeavors. The video touches on quantum computing, utilizing unitary operations and matrix representation. Further, it explores mathematical notation, contrasting Newton's and Leibniz's calculus notations, and considers the impact of notation on mathematical thought. Finally, pedagogical approaches to mathematics are discussed, emphasizing a growth mindset and reducing judgment.

source_title: Visualizing quaternions (4d numbers) with stereographic projection
description: This video uses geometric and algebraic methods to visualize quaternion multiplication in four dimensions. It leverages stereographic projections to map a 4D hypersphere onto a 3D space and a 2D plane, respectively. This approach provides a visual intuition for quaternion multiplication, demonstrating its non-commutative nature, and highlighting its applications in computer graphics, robotics, and quantum mechanics. The historical context of quaternion discovery by William Rowan Hamilton is also presented.

source_title: Quaternions and 3d rotation, explained interactively
description: This video explores 3D rotation computation using quaternions. It contrasts this with Euler angles, highlighting the vulnerability of Euler angles to gimbal lock and numerical precision issues. The video uses interactive visualizations and mathematical equations to illustrate quaternion multiplication for 3D rotations in computer graphics, robotics, and virtual reality. A link to an online tutorial is provided.

source_title: Why 5/3 is a fundamental constant for turbulence
description: This video uses fluid dynamics and optics to visualize turbulent air flow. A laser beam is refracted through a glass rod and passed through a fog-filled container to create a 2D cross-section of the air flow. The resulting image reveals chaotic swirling patterns of varying sizes. The video explores the mathematical challenges of describing turbulence, including the Navier-Stokes equations and Kolmogorov's 5/3 law, which describes how energy cascades down length scales in turbulent flows. The unique characteristics of 3D turbulence are highlighted, including vortex stretching.

source_title: Using topology for discrete problems | The Borsuk-Ulam theorem and stolen necklaces
description: This video uses the Borsuk-Ulam theorem from topology to solve the stolen necklace problem from discrete mathematics. The theorem states that any continuous map from an n-sphere to an (n-1)-dimensional space maps some pair of antipodal points to the same point. This concept is applied to a necklace-division problem, demonstrating a connection between continuous and discrete mathematical structures. The video uses visualizations to illustrate these concepts and their applications in computer science.

source_title: But why is a sphere's surface area four times its shadow?
description: This video uses geometrical methods to derive the formula for the surface area of a sphere (4πR²). It presents two approaches: one leveraging the relationship between a sphere and a circumscribed cylinder; the other connecting the sphere to its projection onto a plane. The second approach utilizes concepts of similar triangles and trigonometry to explain why the area of the projection is 1/4 the sphere’s surface area. The video also extends these concepts to explore the average projected area of arbitrary convex shapes. The video concludes by suggesting that such geometric reasoning provides an intuitive foundation for calculus.

source_title: The most unexpected answer to a counting puzzle
description: This video explores a mathematical problem using physics simulations. By modeling frictionless, elastic collisions of two blocks with differing masses, the number of collisions is shown to approximate the digits of π. The accuracy increases with the ratio of block masses; however, this method is computationally inefficient for higher-precision calculations of π. The presenter highlights the elegance and surprising inefficiency of this π-calculating algorithm, derived from the conservation of energy.

source_title: Why do colliding blocks compute pi?
description: This video explores the unexpected appearance of pi in a physics problem involving two sliding blocks. Using classical mechanics principles of momentum and energy conservation, the problem is mapped to phase space, revealing an elliptical trajectory. Transforming this ellipse into a circle via coordinate rescaling, and employing the inscribed angle theorem, the number of collisions is shown to be related to pi. The approximation arctan(x)≈x for small x is crucial to this result, highlighting a connection between dynamics and geometry.

source_title: How colliding blocks act like a beam of light...to compute pi.
description: This video explores the connection between a block collision puzzle and optics using geometric and physics principles. The number of collisions between blocks of differing masses unexpectedly relates to pi. An alternate solution uses phase space, mapping the system's state to points on a coordinate plane where axes represent block positions. Rescaling coordinates reveals a trajectory analogous to light bouncing between mirrors, where conservation of energy and momentum respectively correspond to constant speed of light and equal angles of incidence and reflection. The number of bounces is determined by the angle between mirrors, which relates to pi for specific mass ratios.

source_title: Cramer's rule, explained geometrically | Chapter 12, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video uses linear algebra to explain Cramer’s rule for solving systems of linear equations. It leverages geometric concepts such as determinants and dot products to visualize solutions in two and three dimensions. The video explains how the determinant of a matrix scales areas and volumes, offering a visual interpretation of Cramer’s rule and highlighting its limitations compared to Gaussian elimination, particularly for higher-dimensional systems. The method's reliance on the determinant's geometric properties is emphasized.

source_title: Differential equations, a tourist's guide | DE1
description: Differential equations describe change, not absolute amounts. Physics uses them to model motion, where force determines acceleration. They come in ordinary (ODE) and partial (PDE) forms. ODEs involve functions of a single variable (often time), while PDEs deal with multiple variables. Numerical methods approximate solutions through finite time steps, offering valuable insight into complex systems even when exact solutions are unavailable. Phase space visualizes states and their rates of change, aiding intuitive understanding of dynamics and stability, and finds application across diverse fields such as ecology and chemistry. Chaos theory adds another layer of complexity, demonstrating the sensitivity of some systems to initial conditions.

source_title: But what is a partial differential equation?  | DE2
description: This video uses intuitive visualizations to explain partial differential equations (PDEs). It contrasts PDEs with ordinary differential equations (ODEs), highlighting the increased complexity of PDEs due to their modeling of infinitely many interacting variables. The heat equation is presented as a solvable PDE, leveraging concepts from thermodynamics and Fourier series. Visual representations using color maps and 3D graphs illustrate the heat distribution and its temporal evolution. The video explains partial derivatives as rates of change, connecting them to the intuition behind second differences in a discrete model, ultimately bridging the concepts to the Laplacian operator. The video concludes by linking the Laplacian to the divergence of the gradient for those familiar with multivariable calculus.

source_title: Solving the heat equation | DE3
description: This video explores the heat equation, a partial differential equation describing heat flow. It uses Fourier series, leveraging sine wave solutions and the principle of linearity, to solve the equation. Boundary conditions, specifically zero slope at the ends, are incorporated for a realistic model, contrasting idealized scenarios. Exponential decay naturally arises in solutions.

source_title: But what is a Fourier series?  From heat flow to drawing with circles | DE4
description: This video explains Fourier series, demonstrating how the sum of rotating vectors, each with constant integer frequency, can produce complex shapes over time. The initial size and angle of each vector determine the resultant shape. The process is described mathematically by a concise formula, initially derived to solve the heat equation in physics. The heat equation's linearity is key to solving it for various initial conditions, often expressed as sums of cosine waves. The video also introduces complex Fourier series, utilizing complex numbers and vectors in the complex plane for computations. Numerical integration methods are presented to calculate coefficients, and the concept of averaging sums is explained.

source_title: Pure Fourier series animation montage
description: This video explores the visualization of mathematical functions using various scientific techniques. It employs complex analysis to map real numbers to complex numbers and presents the results graphically. Further visualizations use geographical data (mapping) and artistic representations, illustrating the diverse applications of mathematical concepts across different scientific disciplines. The video utilizes a tenfold and hundredfold zoom to showcase fractal patterns arising from the visualization of functions in the complex plane.

source_title: e^(iπ) in 3.14 minutes, using dynamics | DE5
description: This video uses calculus to explain the properties of Euler's number (*e*). It defines *e* as the unique function whose derivative equals itself and whose value at zero is one. Using a physical model, the video links *e<sup>t</sup>* to position and velocity on a number line, showing that velocity is always equal to position. Extending to complex numbers, it explains *e<sup>iπ</sup> = -1* by visualizing movement on a complex plane, with velocity as a 90° rotation of position, creating a circular trajectory. The video concludes by noting that *e<sup>iπ</sup>* represents a series, not repeated multiplication.

source_title: The unexpectedly hard windmill question (2011 IMO, Q2)
description: The International Mathematical Olympiad (IMO) is analyzed, focusing on the 2011 competition. Over 500 participants from 101 countries attempted six proof-based problems over two days. Performance data reveals Problem 2, a geometric “windmill” puzzle, unexpectedly stumped many top competitors, highlighting the difficulty in assessing problem complexity and the importance of identifying invariant quantities in problem-solving. Analysis integrates elements of mathematics, statistics, and physics.

source_title: Why do prime numbers make these spirals? | Dirichlet’s theorem and pi approximations
description: Visualizing prime number distribution in polar coordinates reveals striking spiral patterns. These emerge from the interplay of prime number properties with rational approximations of pi. Specifically, the spiral structure is closely linked to residue classes modulo 6 and 44, demonstrating connections between number theory and geometry. Further analysis leveraging complex analysis and Euler’s totient function illuminates the underlying mathematical principles and confirms Dirichlet’s theorem on prime distribution.

source_title: Q&A with Grant, windy walk edition
description: This video explores the intersection of mathematics and other scientific disciplines. It features Claude Shannon's foundational work in information theory, highlighting its impact on computer science. The video also delves into chaos theory, exemplified by Edward Lorenz's work in meteorology. The presenter discusses the contrasting personalities and approaches of pure vs. applied mathematicians, suggesting that a balance of playful exploration and pragmatic application is crucial for scientific advancement. The video concludes by reflecting on the importance of accessible mathematics education.

source_title: Bayes theorem, the geometry of changing beliefs
description: This video explains Bayes' theorem, a core tool in probability theory. The theorem is used in diverse fields including scientific discovery, machine learning, and treasure hunting (as illustrated by a 1988 example). The video explains three levels of understanding Bayes' theorem: (1) knowing what each part of the equation means, (2) understanding why it is true, and (3) knowing when it is useful. A key concept is that new evidence updates prior beliefs, rather than completely determining them. A case study from Kahneman and Tversky's research on human judgment illustrates the concept. The video visually demonstrates Bayes' theorem using area representations of probabilities, offering an intuitive alternative to complex mathematical equations.

source_title: The quick proof of Bayes' theorem
description: This video uses probability theory to explain Bayes’ theorem. It demonstrates the theorem using Venn diagrams and area models, highlighting its mathematical derivation and application in updating beliefs with evidence. The video also addresses common misconceptions, particularly regarding independent events and conditional probabilities, illustrated with coin flips and dice rolls. Finally, it emphasizes the theorem’s utility beyond simple examples, using medical diagnostics as a relevant application.

source_title: Exponential growth and epidemics
description: This video uses epidemiological data and mathematical modeling to analyze COVID-19's exponential growth. Visualizations show the rapid increase in cases outside mainland China. A simple model, ΔNd = E * p * Nd, describes daily case changes (ΔNd) based on existing cases (Nd), average exposure (E), and infection probability (p). A logarithmic scale reveals a near-linear trend, indicating exponential growth. Linear regression analysis quantifies this growth, showing a tenfold increase approximately every 16 days. The video concludes by introducing logistic curves to model the eventual leveling off of growth due to population saturation or changes in E or p. The inflection point is identified as the point where the growth factor approaches one.

source_title: Binomial distributions | Probabilities of probabilities, part 1
description: This video uses Bayesian methods and the binomial distribution to address the problem of estimating the probability of a positive customer experience based on online seller ratings with varying sample sizes. The presenter employs simulations and a formula to show how the probability of observing a given percentage of positive reviews changes with different underlying success rates. The video introduces core probability and statistics concepts.

source_title: Simulating an epidemic
description: Agent-based modeling simulates epidemic spread using the SIR model (Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered). Simulations explore social distancing, identifying/isolating cases, and travel restrictions effects. Results show that early intervention is crucial, while later interventions have limited impact. R, the effective reproductive number, quantifies spread. Central locations significantly accelerate transmission.

source_title: Why “probability of 0” does not mean “impossible” | Probabilities of probabilities, part 2
description: This video explores probability theory, particularly the concept of probability density functions (PDFs). It contrasts discrete probability (where individual events have non-zero probability) with continuous probability (where individual events have zero probability but ranges of events have non-zero probabilities). The video uses coin flips as an example, illustrating how experimental data can inform our understanding of the underlying probability. It introduces measure theory as a unifying framework for handling both discrete and continuous probability. Key mathematical concepts include summation and integration, applied to probability calculations in discrete and continuous settings, respectively.

source_title: Lockdown math announcement
description: This video announces live-streamed math lectures for high school students, focusing on the quadratic formula. The presenter aims to create an engaging learning experience, contrasting with traditional methods. A new technology, developed by former colleagues, will enhance audience interaction, emphasizing a hands-on, paper-based approach to problem-solving. Lectures are planned for Tuesdays and Fridays at noon Pacific Time.

source_title: The DP-3T algorithm for contact tracing (with Nicky Case)
description: This video explains digital contact tracing apps using Bluetooth proximity data and pseudorandom identifiers to alert individuals of potential COVID-19 exposure without compromising user privacy. The approach leverages epidemiological modeling, cryptography, and software engineering to improve upon traditional contact tracing methods. Open-source code facilitates independent verification of the system’s functionality.

source_title: The impossible chessboard puzzle
description: This video presents a mathematical puzzle involving a chessboard and coins. Two prisoners must deduce the location of a key hidden under one square by flipping only one coin. The puzzle's solvability is analyzed, revealing connections to error correction codes in computer science and information theory, specifically Hamming codes. Visualizations using higher-dimensional cubes illustrate the strategy and its limitations for boards with non-power-of-two sizes. The video concludes by demonstrating the inherent impossibility of a solution for chessboards that are not a power of two.

source_title: Group theory, abstraction, and the 196,883-dimensional monster
description: This video explores the mathematical concept of groups and their relation to symmetry. Group theory, using abstract algebra, codifies symmetry; examples shown include the symmetries of a face (C₂), snowflake (D₆), and cube (S₄). The size of a group reflects the preserved structure; a cube's 24 rotational symmetries expand to 48 with reflections, further increasing to 188,743,680 if faces are unconstrained. The largest sporadic group, the “Monster,” has ~8 x 10⁵³ elements, connected to 196,883-dimensional objects in string theory. The classification of finite simple groups (18 infinite families and 26 sporadic groups) is a monumental achievement in mathematics.

source_title: But what are Hamming codes? The origin of error correction
description: This video explains error correction codes, focusing on Hamming codes. It leverages information theory, linear algebra, and digital logic. A simple method using redundant copies is shown, achieving error correction at the cost of 66.7% storage. More sophisticated methods, such as Hamming codes, minimize redundancy while maintaining robust error correction. A 15,11 Hamming code example, implementable in software and hardware, is presented, illustrating the process of error detection and correction.

source_title: Hamming codes part 2: The one-line implementation
description: Hamming codes, a method for error correction in data blocks, are explored. A hands-on approach using multiple parity checks and binary search is presented. An alternative perspective using XOR operations is shown to simplify implementation in both software (single line Python code) and hardware. The efficiency increases with block size, reaching 0.00002 parity bits per data bit for blocks of 1,048,576 bits. Claude Shannon's 1948 information theory provides a theoretical foundation. Reed-Solomon codes offer improved burst-error resilience.

source_title: The medical test paradox, and redesigning Bayes' rule
description: This video uses the medical test paradox to illustrate Bayesian reasoning. A highly accurate test, with 90% sensitivity and 91% specificity, yields a low positive predictive value (∼1/11) for a low prevalence disease (1%). The Bayes factor (likelihood ratio), sensitivity/false positive rate, offers a more intuitive framework for understanding test results, highlighting the independence of prior probability from test accuracy and enabling easier calculation of posterior probability through multiplication. The video contrasts this with the more complex standard Bayesian formula where these factors are intertwined. Using odds instead of probabilities simplifies Bayesian updating, especially when multiple pieces of evidence are considered.

source_title: How (and why) to raise e to the power of a matrix | DE6
description: This video explores matrix exponentiation, utilizing linear algebra and calculus to solve systems of differential equations. Visualizations employing vector fields illustrate the action of matrix exponentials, showing their applications in diverse fields including physics (quantum mechanics via Schrödinger’s equation) and the modeling of dynamic systems such as relationships. Taylor series expansions provide an analytical approach to matrix exponentiation.

source_title: A quick trick for computing eigenvalues | Chapter 15, Essence of linear algebra
description: This video demonstrates a shortcut for calculating eigenvalues of 2x2 matrices. The standard method involves computing the determinant of a modified matrix and solving the resulting characteristic polynomial using the quadratic formula. The presented alternative leverages linear algebra principles: the trace (sum of diagonal elements) gives the mean of the eigenvalues, and the determinant provides their product. This allows direct calculation of eigenvalues via a simplified formula, shown to be especially efficient for matrices arising in quantum mechanics, which frequently use Pauli spin matrices.

source_title: Make math videos! | Summer of Math Exposition announcement
description: This video announces a mathematics exposition contest. Participants submit original math explainers (video, blog post, or interactive game) by August 22nd. Winners are featured in a 3blue1brown video. The video also discusses effective explainer structure (concrete-to-abstract), production quality (topic>production), niche selection, genre awareness, and avoiding irrelevant pattern-matching. Additional resources are provided including Manim animation software and a Discord server.

source_title: Newton’s fractal (which Newton knew nothing about)
description: Newton's method approximates polynomial roots via iterative linearization.
