Educational applications in mathematics and the use of engaging activities were emphasized.

source_title: All UK football road signs are wrong! Join the petition for geometric change!
description: A UK street sign depicts a football composed solely of hexagons, a geometric impossibility. A petition calls for correction to hexagons and pentagons, aligning with the actual geometry of a football. Euler characteristic (Faces-Edges+Vertices=2) is applied to demonstrate that a sphere cannot be composed only of hexagons. A formula is derived for the Euler characteristic of a shape made only of hexagons, demonstrating the impossibility. The relevant UK Traffic Signs Regulations are cited.

source_title: Matt & Hugh: Euler Disk III, The Correctioning
description: This video uses observational analysis of an Euler disk's motion to explore the relationship between wobble and spin rates. The experiment uses a disk spinning on a mirrored surface. Mathematical modeling, specifically employing trigonometric functions and small-angle approximations, reveals discrepancies between theoretical predictions and experimental observations. The analysis involves classical mechanics and addresses viewer feedback, highlighting the importance of considering all factors in scientific modeling.

source_title: Matt & Hugh: the mystery of two balls in a can
description: This video demonstrates a physics experiment involving three balls and an apple juice can. Using engineering principles, a free body diagram is constructed to analyze forces and moments acting on the can. Geometric and trigonometric calculations, including application of the tangent function, determine the minimum force required to prevent the system from tipping. The experiment concludes by verifying theoretical calculations.

source_title: MENACE: the pile of matchboxes which can learn
description: This video documents an experiment in machine learning using a tic-tac-toe playing machine named MENACE, built from 304 matchboxes. Each matchbox represents a game state, containing colored beads indicating possible moves. Human players interact with MENACE, and data on wins, losses, and draws are logged to observe learning over many games. Results show MENACE's improved performance and preference for certain opening moves. Computational simulations of optimal play are compared with the experimental results.

source_title: Back to the Fax Machine
description: This video explores the accuracy of predictions from *Back to the Future Part II* regarding 2015. The presenter uses number theory (palindromic numbers in binary), film analysis (sequels, hands-free gaming), and the history of technology (fax machines). A fax machine's image encoding process is detailed, illustrating the conversion of visual data into binary code for transmission and printing. The video concludes by referencing the historical context of fax technology, dating back to 1843, and its contemporary irrelevance.

source_title: Strictly Come Dancing is Strictly Unfair
description: This video analyzes the fairness of the voting system used in *Strictly Come Dancing*. A statistical model is proposed to evaluate the system's performance. The current method of handling ties in the judges' scores is shown to be unfair, potentially favoring certain couples. Alternative tie-breaking methods, inspired by sports league tables, are explored and evaluated. The analysis reveals the importance of transparent data release to ensure fairness and allow for rigorous evaluation of ranking systems.

source_title: Stats of CERN: How many Higgs per second?
description: This video documents a visit to CERN's Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) experiment. The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) accelerates proton packets (120 billion protons/packet) to 99.99% the speed of light, 2,500 packets per beam direction. These beams collide at a rate of 40 megahertz, yielding ~25 collisions per crossing. Approximately one Higgs boson is produced per billion collisions, resulting in a rate of ~1 Higgs boson per second. Safety features include radiation monitoring and oxygen level alarms.

source_title: Impossible Rubik's Cubes
description: This video examines improperly designed Rubik's Cubes. Disassembly of a standard cube reveals 26 individual components: six center pieces, twelve edge pieces, and eight corner pieces. Incorrect designs, such as a tissue box cover and cufflinks, exhibit impossible color combinations, violating the principle of opposite colors on opposite faces. An Atari 2600 video game and magazine cover depict further examples of this design flaw. An original Rubik's Cube from Hungary, still sealed, illustrates the historical prevalence of such errors. Reverse engineering and solving these flawed cubes forms a novel puzzle-solving challenge.

source_title: The Actual Mathematics of Popping Champagne Corks
description: High-speed camera (6000fps) footage and bubble physics modeling were used to analyze champagne cork ejection. Results show the pop’s frequency correlates with the bottle's geometry and internal gas pressure. Acoustics analysis confirmed a dominant frequency around 600 Hz, varying slightly with temperature. This refutes prior media claims.

source_title: Dodecaplex: the puzzle from the fourth dimension!
description: This video explores the mathematics of four-dimensional shapes, specifically the 120-cell. 3D-printed models of the dodecahedron (a 3D Platonic solid) and sections of the 120-cell were used to demonstrate the concept of Hopf fibration. The video also features a 3D-printed puzzle, the "Dodecaplex," based on the 120-cell, showcasing the challenge of assembling its parts. The puzzle's design demonstrates geometrical and topological principles, and the presenters discuss 3D printing and design limitations in producing the puzzle. Finally, chirality aspects of the puzzle’s solutions were noted.

source_title: How thick is a three-sided coin?
description: This video explores the probability of a three-sided coin landing on its edge vs. a face. Using geometric reasoning and calculations involving the surface area of a sphere and a cylinder, two theoretical models are developed, yielding distinct results. An experimental approach involving 1000 coin tosses and statistical analysis (binomial distribution and normal approximation) is employed to determine the likelihood of observing the experimental data, revealing that neither theoretical model perfectly reflects reality. Further research is proposed to refine the models by exploring additional thickness ratios.

source_title: Calculating π by hand: the Chudnovsky algorithm
description: This video demonstrates the Chudnovsky algorithm for calculating π, a computationally efficient infinite series used to determine π to a high degree of accuracy. The presenter compares this method to a prior, less efficient calculation, illustrating the mathematical concepts of infinite series and convergence. Furthermore, an approximation method for square roots is used, highlighting principles of numerical analysis. The final result, 3.14159265358979, shows the accuracy achieved using the Chudnovsky algorithm.

source_title: How to find a square root
description: This video demonstrates an iterative method for approximating square roots using arithmetic. Employing principles of geometry and numerical analysis, an initial estimate (e.g., √10,005 ≈ 100.025) is refined by analyzing the area of a square. A correction term is calculated and iteratively applied to improve accuracy to a desired level of precision, as shown through the example calculation.

source_title: The Tuning Fork Mystery: unexpected vibrations
description: This video explores acoustics and classical mechanics using tuning forks of varying lengths. Experiments involved striking forks and measuring frequencies (Hz) using a smartphone spectrum analyzer app. Results showed that placing a fork on a table doubles its frequency, due to added vertical vibrational modes. A mathematical model, incorporating centripetal force (mv²/r), explains the frequency increase. Furthermore, a computational simulation of coin flipping is mentioned, considering factors like gravity, friction, and coin properties to determine probabilities.

source_title: The Tuning Fork Mystery: an unexpected update
description: An acoustics experiment investigated frequency doubling in vibrating tuning forks. Unexpected results prompted a follow-up analysis of user-submitted videos. Differences in tuning fork geometry (square vs. circular cross-section) correlated with observed frequency changes. This suggests a Poissons ratio effect explains the variation, implying material stress affects vibrational modes.

source_title: Inside an Antimatter Factory
description: This video explores antimatter production at CERN’s Antimatter Factory. Antimatter, possessing opposite charge to its matter counterpart, annihilates upon contact, releasing energy and photons. The factory, using magnetic fields, creates anti-atoms, notably anti-hydrogen. The process involves decelerating antiprotons from the Proton Synchrotron using iridium and other metals. Further experiments, such as GBAR and ALPHA, investigate antimatter’s properties, particularly gravitational behavior, utilizing Dirac's equation from quantum theory and non-Euclidean geometry. Precision measurements of anti-hydrogen energy levels are made to ten decimal places, aiming to identify discrepancies with theoretical predictions.

source_title: The Rug Puzzle: how many triangles?
description: An 8-year-old's question about counting triangles in a 18x20 grid rug sparked a viral maths challenge. Initial estimates (720) overlooked larger triangles. Solutions involved manual counting, computer programming (Python example shown), and animation. The challenge highlights combinatorics and computational approaches to geometric problems, showcasing engagement across multiple scientific disciplines.

source_title: Psychic Pets: can your pet predict the World Cup results?
description: This video explores the intersection of animal behavior, statistics, and media studies. Inspired by Paul the psychic octopus, the presenters hypothesize that a large enough sample of pet predictions could identify genuinely predictive animals. An experiment involving a dog and tennis balls, with results recorded via smartphone, tests this hypothesis. The presenter also discusses the probability of accurate predictions and the scaling of costs with the number of participants. A separate experiment uses a chameleon and food bowls to test the predictive capabilities of a different animal.

source_title: How many different World Cup results can a team have?
description: This video uses combinatorics and probability to calculate the number of potential outcomes for a World Cup team. A group stage with 3 games (win, lose, or draw) yields 27 possible outcomes (3³). The knockout stage, with 4 win-lose games, has 16 outcomes (2⁴). Combining these stages, a total of 161 possible outcomes exist for a team's tournament. However, considering only definitive outcomes (wins/losses), and accounting for possible knockout-stage exits, the number of possible paths is reduced to 142. The presenter suggests using this framework for educational purposes.

source_title: Why do whole oranges float, but peeled oranges sink?
description: This video investigates why a peeled orange sinks while an unpeeled one floats. A simple experiment demonstrates this. Two hypotheses are tested: air trapped under the peel and peel density. Underwater peeling reveals air release, confirming the first hypothesis. A mass and water displacement experiment shows that the peel's density is less than that of the water it displaces, supporting the second hypothesis. The combined effect of air and peel density explains the observed phenomenon.

source_title: Can animals predict the future? Meet Barry the Psychic Labrador!
description: A behavioral experiment tested whether a dog could predict the outcomes of football matches. A Labrador Retriever, Barry, correctly chose the winning team in four out of five trials, exceeding a 1/54 chance with random selection. A larger study including 133 pets yielded similar results for the first England match (52/133 for England), suggesting that pet prediction accuracy may not be due to psychic abilities but rather large sample size and chance. Further analysis of biases and statistical significance is needed to evaluate predictive abilities.

source_title: How to detect bank fraud with maths
description: Monzo bank's fraud detection utilizes data analysis to identify suspicious transactions. Initial analysis flagged a data breach at Ticketmaster, resulting in 40% of fraudulent transactions being linked to it. Further analysis increased this figure to 70%. This disproportionate volume, considering only 0.8% of Monzo customers used Ticketmaster, suggests the breach as the source. A typographical error in the expiry date on compromised cards provided conclusive evidence. Future automated systems aim to proactively flag statistically significant fraud patterns.

source_title: THE SCUTOID: did scientists discover a new shape?
description: Biologists observed unusual 3D cell arrangements in epithelial tissues, defying typical prism/truncated pyramid models. Mathematicians, collaborating with physicists and computer scientists, modeled these structures using Voronoi techniques to predict optimal configurations. 3D-printed scutoids—named after a beetle’s similar body part—demonstrate the predicted stable packing.

source_title: Making a physical Lissajous curve
description: This video explores Lissajous figures, parametric plots generated by two sine functions. A mechanical device, using two independently controlled rotating turntables, is constructed to physically draw these figures. The resulting plots are compared to those generated using GeoGebra and Excel simulations. Discrepancies are analyzed in terms of mechanical limitations of the device and the precision of the speed ratio.

source_title: Does daylight savings kill people?
description: Analysis of the Blue Cross Blue Shield Cardiovascular Consortium database from March 2010-Sept 2013 revealed a 24% increase in acute myocardial infarction (AMI) on Mondays following daylight savings time (DST) spring changes, with a 21% decrease on Tuesdays following DST fall changes. However, weekly AMI rates showed no net change. This indicates DST impacts sleep cycles, affecting cardiovascular health.

source_title: Ordinals vs Cardinals (and how many algebraic numbers are there?)
description: This video explores the mathematical concepts of ordinal and cardinal numbers. Ordinals, used for ordering, differ from cardinals, used for quantity. The video highlights Cantor's proof of the countability of algebraic numbers, defined as roots of polynomials with rational coefficients. A method for ordering algebraic numbers based on polynomial "height" is presented, demonstrating a finite number of polynomials for each height. The video concludes by illustrating an ordering of algebraic numbers, incorporating real and complex numbers.

source_title: How to estimate a population using statisticians
description: Estimating wildlife population size is challenging. This study uses capture-recapture methods at the Royal Statistical Society's conference to estimate the number of statisticians. Initial sampling and subsequent re-sampling, employing stickers as markers, are analyzed using frequency tables and probability distributions. Results indicate an approximate population size of 138, with limitations acknowledged due to non-random sampling.

source_title: Stand-up comedy routine using a live spherical camera
description: This video uses spherical cameras and mathematical principles to create immersive 360° video. The presenter, with the assistance of colleagues, demonstrates live mathematical visualization techniques involving software and 3D spatial arrangement. Challenges in processing the raw footage into a seamless spherical view are discussed, with solutions involving rectilinear projection methods. The process ultimately allows for creative manipulation of live video feeds, as illustrated through juggling.

source_title: The equations behind my live spherical footage
description: This video demonstrates the Droste effect using live 360° video and computational mathematics. A green screen is digitally replaced with a recursive projection of the video onto a plane. A programmer uses the complex plane to map the spherical footage. The resulting image is then manipulated using mathematical functions (logarithm and exponential), and polar coordinates to create a Droste effect. The demonstration includes live juggling to showcase the application of the effect.

source_title: Infinite DVD unboxing video: Festival of the Spoken Nerd
description: This video documents the unboxing of a DVD containing the “Festival of the Spoken Nerd”. The presenter demonstrates DVD playback on a Blu-ray player, highlighting high-resolution video and selectable chapters and audio tracks. The included booklet provides show details & copyright information. Topics covered include physics (microwaves, gravitational waves), chemistry (elements), and mathematics (Pi). The presenter notes the availability of a high-definition digital download.

source_title: How many calendars are there?
description: This video explores the Gregorian calendar's structure. Analysis reveals that, excluding February's variable length, each month can begin on one of seven days, resulting in 14 possible calendar variations per year. This pattern repeats every 400 years (400 x 365 + 97 days), as demonstrated via mathematical calculations and illustrated using examples. The video also notes the existence of other calendar systems, and the cultural significance of date-keeping.

source_title: 2019 facts in 2 mins 19 seconds
description: This video presents number puzzles based on the year 2019. Solutions involve arithmetic operations, including exponentiation, concatenation, and factorials, demonstrating number theory principles. The presenter introduces a formula generating 2019 using any single digit (except 0). A second puzzle challenges viewers to find four digits whose powers, in various orders, sum to 2019, exploring combinatorics and power functions. A link to a PDF detailing additional mathematical representations of 2019 is provided.

source_title: Happy Thirdsday: finding a third using only halves
description: This video explores mathematical concepts related to the fraction ⅓. It uses a rope-based demonstration to illustrate iterative approximation of ⅓ through halving, demonstrating the principle of converging upon a solution by reducing error. This is further explained graphically through the intersection of y=x and y=(1-x)/2, highlighting fixed-point iteration in numerical analysis. Pedagogical applications using mnemonics and classroom activities are also discussed.

source_title: Superpermutations: the maths problem solved by 4chan
description:
An anonymous 4chan user’s 2011 proof of a superpermutation’s minimal length was recently verified. This video uses combinatorics & graph theory to explain the proof. The shortest superpermutation for three objects has length nine; for four, length 33. For five objects, there are eight equally optimal superpermutations of length 153. A computer scientist utilized the Lin-Kernighan heuristic to find a shorter superpermutation (length 872) for six objects, improving on the previously known upper bound. This method establishes a new upper bound of n!+(n-1)!+(n-2)!+(n-3)!+n-3.
Further research suggests this can be improved to n-4.

source_title: Bad Rounding: ⌊Trump vs Obamacare⌋
description: This video explores the impact of rounding in diverse real-world contexts. Analysis of the Affordable Care Act reveals how a rounding method affected insurance costs, resulting in a three times higher charge for some customers, compared to the initial 3.49 times. A patent law case involving a 1% solution concentration highlights how rounding to one significant figure (0.8%) in scientific contexts differs from rounding to the nearest whole percent (1%), leading to legal disputes. Finally, a German election example demonstrates how rounding to the nearest whole percent (5%) prevented the Green Party’s 4.97% vote share from securing parliamentary representation. The video uses illustrative examples and quantitative data to expose the importance of precision in various scientific and legal domains.

source_title: How fast is a bullet? [featuring: pendulum calculation]
description: This experiment used a ballistic pendulum and engineering principles to calculate bullet velocity. A .22 target rifle was fired into a pendulum (approx. 10kg & 2.84kg) of stacked paper. The pendulum's swing distance (26mm & 95mm) was measured. Bullet fragments (2.6g total recovered) were weighed. Using conservation of momentum and energy, along with small-angle approximations and pendulum period calculations, bullet velocities of 324 m/s and 343 m/s were obtained, closely matching the manufacturer's stated velocity of 323.4 m/s.

source_title: Humble Pi: plane wrong
description: This video uses the book "Humble Pi" to discuss how binary number limitations in computer systems caused multiple near-disasters. A 32-bit counter in the Los Angeles air traffic control center, counting milliseconds, rolled over after ~49 days, causing a loss of contact with 800 aircraft. Similarly, a 31-bit counter in a Boeing 787 electrical power system could have caused a mid-flight power failure after ~248 days. These incidents highlight the importance of robust software engineering, systems design, and numerical analysis in aviation and beyond.

source_title: Humble Pi: Los Angeles crime and Null Island
description: This video discusses geographical data errors in crime mapping and online venue searches. In Los Angeles, 4% of crimes reported between October 2008 and March 2009 were incorrectly geolocated to the LAPD headquarters due to illegible handwritten addresses. A time-on-site technique was used to correct this. A similar issue arose when searching for book launch venues online, with one venue incorrectly plotted to Null Island (0°0′0″N 0°0′0″E), a location used to flag geocoding errors. The video utilizes cartography, database management and geographic information systems (GIS) to illustrate these spatial data challenges.

source_title: Pi Day 2019: calculating π with a balancing beam
description:
This video uses an infinite series to calculate π² /6, by applying the concept of torque in physics. A 6m beam is balanced with copies of the author's book, "Humble Pi", acting as unit masses at calculated distances, achieving a surprisingly accurate approximation of π.
The experiment combines mathematical analysis, weighing with a balance scale, and physical principles of torque and equilibrium.

source_title: New Superpermutations Discovered!
description: A shorter-than-previously-known superpermutation on seven symbols (length=5,906) was discovered via a YouTube comment. This result, found by Bogdan Coanda, refines theoretical minimums discussed in previous work. The discovery spurred further algorithmic developments, culminating in a musical performance of the sequence on a self-playing Yamaha Disklavier piano, showcasing the intersection of mathematics, computer science, and music.

source_title: Bayesian Statistics with Hannah Fry
description: This video uses historical research to locate the home of Thomas Bayes (1702-1761), a Nonconformist minister and mathematician. A Bayesian statistical experiment is recreated, using balls thrown onto a table to illustrate how new evidence updates prior beliefs, generating a probability distribution that peaks with multiple trials, thereby illustrating Bayesian statistical methods.

source_title: When Buildings Wobble: with Paul Shepherd
description: This video demonstrates the concept of resonance in structures using a vibration table and a Jenga tower. A low-frequency motor, similar to one from a washing machine, is used to simulate building vibrations. The experiment shows that at specific frequencies, the tower's oscillations increase dramatically, leading to collapse. This illustrates a practical application of physics and engineering principles for civil engineering undergraduates.

source_title: Why didn't GPS crash?
description: This video explores the 1999 rollover of the Global Positioning System (GPS) week counter, a 10-bit binary number. Using a pre-2010 GPS device, the presenter demonstrates the rollover to week 0, showing the inaccurate date and time displayed. The presenter then compares location data with a modern device, highlighting the accuracy of modern GPS systems which utilize a larger 13-bit counter and increased satellite signal processing capabilities. The implications for timekeeping and data storage are discussed.

source_title: The Difference of Two Squares
description: This video uses algebraic and geometric methods to prove that every odd number is the difference between two squares. It then explores whether this holds for even numbers, using modular arithmetic to demonstrate that only numbers with remainders of 0, 1, or 3 when divided by 4 are expressible as the difference of two squares.

source_title: Recursive PowerPoint Presentations [Gone Fractal!]
Calculator Number Trick: rectangle patterns
description: Any rectangular number sequence on a calculator's number pad, when concatenated, is divisible by 11. This is demonstrable via algebraic manipulation of the resulting numerical expression. The presenter verifies the pattern empirically, and extends the concept to non-rectangular shapes and number bases. This observation integrates number theory, algebra, and experimental mathematics.

source_title: What's the story with log(1 + 2 + 3)?
description: This video explores the mathematical properties of logarithms, specifically addressing a viral internet meme. The meme incorrectly states log(A+B+C) = log(A)+log(B)+log(C). The video uses number theory to show this is false except when A=1. It then explores solutions where the sum of a set of numbers equals their product, visualizing solutions using a scatter plot and linear equations. Finally, a log-based meme employing the golden ratio is proposed.

source_title: Are odd-numbered mobius-loop cogs possible?
description: This video explores the mathematical properties of gear systems, specifically focusing on the impossibility of creating a closed loop with an odd number of standard gears. The presenter demonstrates this principle using a poster and the design of the UK £2 coin. A solution using a Möbius strip configuration is presented, alongside 3D-printed models. The video concludes by advertising Jane Street's WISE and WiTT summer programs for women in STEM, which support STEM education and quantitative trading careers.

source_title: Curvahedra: how many faces make a polyhedron
description: This video explores the mathematical principles underlying the design of Curvahedra, 3D objects constructed from laser-cut pieces. Inspired by Bathsheba Grossman's sculptures, Curvahedra utilizes a novel connector design allowing for flexible assembly. The video demonstrates the application of Descartes' Theorem and the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem in predicting the resulting polyhedral structures, showcasing the interplay between geometry and topology. Different Curvahedra models, made of paper and metal, are presented, with the latter serving as a large-scale illustration of the theoretical concepts discussed.

source_title: Eclipses can be approximated the same way as π. [ONE TAKE!]
description: This video uses a solar eclipse to illustrate the concept of approximating irrational numbers, specifically pi. Observational astronomy techniques are employed to capture the eclipse. A scale model is created with cardboard cutouts to visually represent the relative sizes and distances of the Sun and Moon. The synodic and nodical months are introduced with their durations provided in days. Finally, continued fractions are used to show how rational approximations improve with added terms.

source_title: How to mathematically hang a picture (badly).
description: This video explores mathematical solutions to a physics-based puzzle. Two methods are presented for hanging a picture using two hooks and string such that removing any hook causes the picture to fall. A third method is shown, referencing a similar puzzle solved via knot theory and braid group representation, leading to discussion of algorithmic approaches and the relationship between seemingly disparate mathematical concepts.

source_title: Can we film a stroboscopic helicopter?
description: Analysis of stroboscopic effects in video footage demonstrates the relationship between camera frame rate (f), object rotation rate (r), and number of blades (n). A simple formula, nr=kf (where k is a constant integer), predicts when a rotating object will appear stationary. This principle was experimentally verified using a helicopter, precisely controlling camera frame rate to match the rotor's apparent standstill. Aerial cinematography techniques and mathematical modeling were employed.

source_title: Can you solve The Frog Problem?
description: A frog hops across a river of lily pads. At each pad, it randomly chooses a direction: forward or to the next pad. A mathematician and a comedian use simulation and analytical methods to estimate expected jumps to cross. The simulation, implemented in Python and GameMaker, suggests an average number of hops which increases with river width. A recursive formula was also proposed.

source_title: Is the London Underground knotted?
description: This video explores the mathematical concept of knots in the context of the London Underground. Using observational data and a smartphone inclinometer, the presenter and collaborators map a trefoil knot along the Tube lines, analyzing the spatial relationships between different lines at various depths. Quantitative data on gradients are also collected. The results provide insights into the topological properties of the network and how it can be simplified to a basic knot.

source_title: How to make a fold-and-cut bat for Halloween!
description: The Fold and Cut Theorem in mathematics, demonstrated via paper-folding and cutting, is explained. A practical application is presented using an A4 sheet, folded and cut to form a bat shape. Variations are shown, demonstrating the impact of altered angles and cuts on the final shape. Additional design strategies for creating different bat shapes are also illustrated.

source_title: The unbelievable solution to the 100 prisoner puzzle.
description: This video explores a probability puzzle using experimental methods. Ten participants, representing prisoners, sequentially select from ten numbered drawers containing cards with numbers 1-10. Each prisoner can open five drawers. The success rate (35%) surpasses the naive 0.1% probability of randomly finding one's number, highlighting the power of a collective strategy in probability. Python code was used for exhaustive analysis of all 3,628,800 permutations, revealing the surprising 31.2% success rate for 100 prisoners. The experiment integrates elements of mathematics, statistics, and computer science.

source_title: Help, our train home is making 9 quintillion stops.
description: A Twitter user reported a train app displaying 9 quintillion stops. The presenter investigated, finding the actual number to be 9,223,372,036,854,775,798. This is close to 2⁶³, reflecting a binary counting system. Many computing systems use 8-bit integers (max 255), limiting values. The presenter hypothesized the app used a 63-bit signed integer, explaining the displayed value. Converting to hexadecimal reveals a leading 7, confirming a signed integer overflow.

source_title: Checking the exact angle of parking bays.
description: This video uses field observation and experimentation to verify the accuracy of a 60° angled parking bay sign in Sydney, Australia. Using chalk and string, a 60° angle is approximated, and measurements of the resulting isosceles triangle are taken. Applying the Law of Cosines, and using a calculator, the actual angle is calculated as 60.49°. This closely matches the sign, demonstrating a practical application of geometric principles and trigonometry. A final graph shows how parking bay width and area vary with angle, indicating the 60° angle as a reasonable compromise between space efficiency and road usage.

source_title: Synchronising Metronomes in a Spreadsheet
description: This video uses coupled oscillators to demonstrate synchronization. The presenter uses metronomes on a board to show how oscillations, initially out of phase, synchronize due to the coupled system’s dynamics. This is mathematically modeled using the Kuramoto model, with computational results shown via spreadsheet and sine wave graphs. The demonstration relates to physics, mathematics and engineering principles observed in the behavior of large-scale structures.

source_title: How to keep an open secret with mathematics.
description: This video describes Shamir's Secret Sharing system, a cryptographic technique using polynomial interpolation. A secret is encoded as the y-intercept of a polynomial; shares are points on the polynomial. Linear polynomials require 2 points for reconstruction, quadratics 3, and so on. Using modular arithmetic with a large prime prevents inference from partial shares. The system's application in Bitcoin security and VPN usage is also discussed.

source_title: Visiting every Platform Zero in the UK in one day!
description: This video documents a journey to find all UK train platforms numbered zero. Observations of platform signage, architecture, and train scheduling are presented. The journey involves train travel and observation of different station designs and infrastructure. The video also incorporates elements of mathematics and computer science (binary numbering systems) to explain the potential rationale behind the use of "0" as a platform number. Social interactions with fellow travelers are also shown.

source_title: Does The Average Person Exist?
description: This video uses the 1950 Anthropometric Survey of US Air Force personnel to illustrate statistical concepts. The study, involving over 4000 subjects and 132 body measurements, aimed to define the “average man.” Anthropological data analysis revealed no such individual exists due to high variability in human body dimensions. This highlights limitations of using averages in design, particularly for engineering applications where a range of sizes must be accommodated.

source_title: The Datasaurus Dozen
description: This video explores the limitations of summary statistics in data analysis, illustrating how identical mean and standard deviation values can yield vastly different data visualizations. Using the Datasaurus Dozen dataset, the presenters demonstrate that diverse data distributions can share the same descriptive statistics, highlighting the necessity of data visualization for accurate interpretation. A software program is used to generate and manipulate datasets; simulated annealing is employed in the algorithm. The findings underscore the critical role of visual representation in preventing misleading conclusions based solely on summary statistics.

source_title: When Spreadsheets Attack!
description: Spreadsheet errors cost millions. Analysis of spreadsheets from the Utah State Board of Education and JP Morgan Chase revealed significant financial miscalculations due to faulty formulas. A study by the European Spreadsheet Risks Interest Group (EuSpRIG) found errors in >90% of spreadsheets. A subsequent analysis of 15,770 spreadsheets revealed that 24% contained errors, averaging 755 mistakes per spreadsheet. One contained 83,273. Microsoft Excel's autocorrect features were implicated.

source_title: Why 02/02/2020 is the most palindromic date ever.
description: This video explores palindromic dates (e.g., 02/02/2020) using US and UK date formats. Analysis reveals 366 such dates per 10,000 years, with 12 dates common to both formats. The frequency of overlapping palindromic dates and split palindromes (e.g., 02/02 with 333 days left in 2020) is quantified. The rarity of these events is highlighted, particularly those that are both palindromic dates and split palindromes within a year; only one example (02/02/2020) exists within the current deca-millennium. Finally, viewer demographics are presented (37.5% subscribed).

source_title: Will a falling pencil hit the table? We do the maths!
description: This video uses experimental physics to explore the relationship between linear and angular momentum. A pencil balanced on its point is struck, resulting in linear and rotational motion. Applying classical mechanics, the experiment demonstrates that the impulse (force*time) equals the change in linear momentum (mass*velocity). Furthermore, angular momentum is shown to depend on the moment of inertia and angular velocity, with a derived relationship between linear velocity, angular velocity, and the angle of impact. Trigonometry is employed to analyze the angle at which the pencil impacts the table.

source_title: Calculating π by hand the Isaac Newton way: Pi Day 2020
description: This video documents a recreation of Isaac Newton's 1666 calculation of π using historical methods. Employing a modified version of Newton's infinite series, a team manually calculated π to multiple decimal places, demonstrating historical mathematical techniques and highlighting the challenges of pre-computer computation. The collaborative experiment integrates history of science, mathematics, and potentially education.

source_title: Why do people keep getting this wrong‽
description: This video analyzes a tweet claiming Mike Bloomberg could have given each American $1 million, given his campaign spending. The presenter performs a division calculation ($500 million / 327 million people ≈ $1.53/person), demonstrating the error in the initial claim. Cognitive psychology is explored, suggesting the mistake stems from humans' intuitive difficulty with large-number arithmetic and unit handling, a topic further discussed in the presenter's book, *Humble Pi*. The video also shows examples of fair money distribution calculations.

source_title: MPMP: Can you spin the table?
description: This video presents a combinatorial optimization problem. Seven investors, represented by cards 1-7, each with a unique industry, must be seated around a circular table. The goal is to determine if a seating arrangement always exists such that at least two investors are seated opposite their corresponding industry card. The presenter uses a plate as a visual aid for the circular table and explores various seating arrangements, ultimately demonstrating the problem's solvability and inviting viewers to submit solutions via an online form.

source_title: Why is the Apple Calendar so broken?
description: This video investigates a calendar bug in iOS 11, where scrolling backward past 1849 causes calendar data to vanish. Software updates to iOS 13.4 are shown to resolve this issue, which is hypothesized to be due to the limitations of 32-bit signed integers for Unix time. The presenter uses WolframAlpha for calculations to support this theory and shows a related 64-bit system.

source_title: MPMP: Can you play Scrabble over a video call?
description: This video explores a problem in recreational mathematics concerning the randomization of Scrabble tiles for remote play. Two players, separated by distance, each possess a full Scrabble tile set. The challenge involves developing a method to ensure both players obtain a similar random distribution of tiles, mimicking the process of drawing from a single bag. Using computational methods and simulations, including a quantum random number generator, the presenter investigates different shuffling algorithms to achieve this goal, with quantitative analysis of the results shown. A novel “2-3 shuffle” method is proposed and tested.

source_title: Can you crack the face-down card game?
description: This video presents a card game requiring two players. Player one arranges four face-down cards so not all are face down. Player two, with eyes closed, requests cards to be flipped, aiming to make all cards face down. In a demonstration, player one required eight guesses while a second attempt using a strategic approach took only one. The video proposes a mathematical puzzle: what is the minimum number of moves to guarantee success? Points are awarded for speed and optimal strategies on a leaderboard. A three-card variation and programming aspects are also briefly mentioned.

source_title: The Parker Machine: it's 80% accurate.
description: This video features a demonstration of a present-scanning machine with 80% accuracy in identifying whether a gift contains a smartphone. The experiment, involving 100 gifts (5 smartphones), uses a probabilistic approach and highlights the concept of false positives in testing. Mathematical modeling and engineering principles are applied to design and evaluate the machine's performance, revealing a 20% false negative rate. The demonstration links these concepts to real-world applications such as cancer screening.

source_title: The Stack Folding Challenge
description: This video presents a paper-folding combinatorics challenge. A sheet of paper is folded and letters are written on the sections. The goal is to fold the paper such that when unfolded, the letters are in alphabetical order. Two example challenges are presented, with solutions available online. The presenter introduces a meta-challenge: determining the total number of possible solutions, considering constraints on letter placement and orientation. Further challenges with varied parameters are proposed.

source_title: Complex Fibonacci Numbers?
description: This video explores the Fibonacci sequence, extending it to negative numbers and utilizing the Binet formula. Experimental data from a math puzzle showed 17.2% of participants used negative Fibonacci numbers. Analysis revealed that the ratio between consecutive terms approaches the golden ratio (φ) in the positive direction and its negative inverse (-1/φ) in the negative direction. Using Python and GeoGebra, visualizations of the sequence in the complex plane were generated, demonstrating a spiral pattern for complex values of n; and a 3D plot showing the undulating real and imaginary components of the sequence. The limit of the alternating areas under the resulting curve is shown to be (2/5)ln(φ)/π.

source_title: The almost impossible chessboard puzzle
description: This video explores a mathematical puzzle framed as a prison escape scenario. Two participants, separated into different rooms, must collaboratively solve a puzzle involving a chessboard and coins to unlock a key. The puzzle uses concepts from probability, combinatorics, and information theory. In a simplified version, with two coins and a 50% chance of success, they devise a strategy based on binary encoding and modular arithmetic. The more complex 64-coin version, employing a 6-bit binary encoding scheme, is also presented along with visualizations. The solution relies on the parity of coin arrangements to communicate the key’s location.

source_title: Why do calculators get this wrong? (We don't know!)
description: This video explores the numerical properties of π using a calculator and Python programming. The expression (11⁶/13) unexpectedly yields a rational multiple of π on a Casio fx-83GT PLUS calculator. This result is analyzed using number theory and the Farey algorithm to approximate the result. Further examples show the calculator's behavior is not consistent. The video concludes by highlighting the Jane Street Women in Trading and Technology event.

source_title: Ellipsoids and The Bizarre Behaviour of Rotating Bodies
description: This video uses footage of a book spinning in zero gravity to explore rigid-body dynamics. Analysis of the observed behavior, combining engineering and mathematical principles, particularly Euler's equations, reveals instabilities in certain rotational axes. Visualizations utilizing ellipsoids illustrate the relationships between kinetic energy and angular momentum in three dimensions, demonstrating that the system's motion is constrained by the intersection of energy and momentum ellipsoids. The video concludes by highlighting the principles of conservation of energy and angular momentum.

source_title: Does "land area" assume a country is perfectly flat?
description: This video investigates inconsistencies in reported national land areas. Using GIS analysis and trigonometric calculations on high-resolution elevation data, the discrepancy between reported and actual area is quantified. The impact of terrain on area calculations is demonstrated for the UK, highlighting the fractal nature of coastlines. For larger, more mountainous countries like Switzerland, this effect is significant.

source_title: What is the biggest tangent of a prime?
description: This video explores the intersection of number theory and trigonometry. A large prime number (1,169,809,...911) was identified where the tangent of the number exceeds the number itself. This was verified computationally using WolframAlpha. The frequency of primes was discussed, relating to the natural logarithm of a number's magnitude. The video concludes by suggesting a potential correlation between the number's primality and the trigonometric property, warranting further investigation.

source_title: Landmark Numbers and Bad Number Analogies
description: This video explores the use of landmark numbers to improve understanding of large quantities. It leverages concepts from statistics and economics, illustrating how common reference points (like a double-decker bus) aid comprehension of otherwise abstract scales. Examples include comparisons of national budgets and Jeff Bezos’ net worth using easily grasped metrics, thus highlighting the cognitive benefits of intuitive units in data visualization and communication.

source_title: Orbital Maths at NASA with Chris Hadfield
description: Orbital mechanics principles are derived, using Newton’s second law (F=ma) and the law of universal gravitation (F=GMm/r²) to determine the velocity required for an object to maintain a given orbit. This derivation incorporates principles of classical mechanics, celestial mechanics, and vector calculus. Quantitative insights demonstrate an inverse relationship between orbital velocity and distance from Earth's center. Astronaut Chris Hadfield's experience provides context for the practical challenges and intuitive limits of these calculations in real-world space navigation, particularly during proximity operations.

source_title: The Rocket Equation: Mathematician vs Astronaut
description: This video uses the principles of classical mechanics and calculus to derive the rocket equation, illustrating how the change in a rocket’s velocity depends on the exhaust velocity and the ratio of initial-to-final mass. The equation is applied to low Earth orbit, with quantitative estimates of payload-to-fuel ratios and launch velocities for various rocket types. The experience of a human astronaut during launch is also discussed.

source_title: Why is there no equation for the perimeter of an ellipse‽
description: This video explores the mathematical properties of ellipses and compares various formulas for approximating their perimeters. It covers the concepts of major and minor axes (a and b), eccentricity (e), and a derived parameter (h). Experimental methods include a visual demonstration of ellipse construction using string and pins. Quantitative analysis compares approximation errors of different formulas, including a novel formula developed by the presenter. The video also advertises internships at Jane Street.

source_title: General Relativity: Top 05 Mishaps [inc INTERSTELLAR]
description: This video explores common misconceptions surrounding Einstein’s theories of relativity. It differentiates special relativity (velocity-based time dilation) from general relativity (gravity-based time dilation), illustrating these concepts with thought experiments. The video highlights the practical application of general relativity in GPS systems, noting the 38.4 µs/day time dilation correction needed for accurate positioning. It also discusses the visual effects in the film *Interstellar*, showcasing how these effects were created with specialized ray-tracing software and scientific input.

source_title: UK Government loses data because of Excel mistake.
description: The UK government temporarily lost 15,841 positive COVID-19 test results due to an Excel spreadsheet error. The row limit (1,048,576; 2²⁰) in the newer .xlsx format was exceeded, but the older .xls format (65,536 rows; 2¹⁶) was used. A 2016 study found auto-correct errors in 19.6% of 35,175 Excel files from 3,597 research papers. Experts advise using databases for critical data; spreadsheets are acceptable for less critical applications.

source_title: What is a Vampire Matrix?
description: This video explores mathematical curiosities. First, "troll maths" examples are shown, where simplification of fractions is deceptively achieved by cancelling digits. Second, "vampire matrices" are introduced, where squaring a matrix results in a scalar multiple of the original. Linear algebra concepts such as the characteristic polynomial and determinant are used to explain these examples. Finally, examples of larger matrices exhibiting similar properties are presented.

source_title: Why do Biden's votes not follow Benford's Law?
description: Benford's Law, stating that leading digits in naturally occurring datasets are not uniformly distributed, was examined for election data. Analysis of Chicago precinct vote totals revealed non-uniformity in leading digits for both Biden and Trump. However, a detailed analysis using a larger dataset, and including the examination of trailing digits, suggested that deviations from Benford's Law in the election data were not necessarily indicative of fraud, but rather a consequence of the vote totals being clustered around a mean value. Statistical analysis of vote distributions further supported this conclusion.

source_title: Do these scatter plots reveal fraudulent vote-switching in Michigan?
description: This video analyzes claims of election fraud in Michigan’s 2020 election using scatter plots. The analysis compares vote percentages by party vs. individual candidate, revealing a methodological flaw: percentages cannot be directly subtracted. Replicating the analysis with a standard line of best fit shows no evidence of the claimed vote switching. The presenter advocates for rigorous data testing before publicizing findings.

source_title: Can you solve the banana puzzle?
description: A mass-based physics puzzle, posed to high school students, is analyzed. A 1.6kg bunch of bananas is weighed using a pulley system. Responses showed 50.5% of students selected £0.80, 37.3% chose £1.60, and 12.3% guessed £3.20. A recreated experiment using 0.8kg bananas demonstrates tension forces. The video concludes with a discussion of work, force, and distance in mechanical systems; Work = Force * Distance.

source_title: What was the first (known) maths mistake?
description: Analysis of Sumerian clay tablets (3400-3000 BCE) from Uruk, modern-day Iraq, reveals an early numerical system used for barley allocation record-keeping. The system, employing five distinct symbols with base-10 and base-60 elements, shows calculations for beer production. Analysis of 18 tablets reveals a common error in totalling, suggesting cognitive limitations of unaided human calculation, highlighting the crucial role of mathematics in societal development and the evolution of written language.

source_title: Why was Biden's win calculated to be ONE IN A QUADRILLION?
description: This video analyzes statistical claims regarding the 2020 US Presidential election. A 1 in a quadrillion probability of a Biden victory in four key states is cited. The analysis uses statistical methods, including Z-scores, to assess the likelihood of such an outcome. The presenter argues that the statistical test's assumptions of independent events and homogenous populations are invalid due to differences in early vs. postal voting, and demographic factors. Historical election data across multiple states are used to support this.

source_title: Why π^π^π^π could be an integer (for all we know!).
description: This video explores the properties of integers, rational, irrational, and transcendental numbers. It investigates whether raising transcendental numbers (like π and *e*) to the power of other transcendental numbers results in an integer. Computational methods and analysis of existing π digit calculations (up to 50 trillion digits) demonstrate the computational infeasibility of directly verifying this for π^(π^(π^π)). The video concludes by proposing Schanuel's conjecture as a potential theoretical approach.

source_title: Calculating π with Avogadro's Number
description: This video uses a chemistry experiment to calculate pi. A solution of oleic acid in pentane is dropped onto a water surface dusted with lycopodium powder; the resulting circle’s area is measured. The number of oleic acid molecules is calculated using Avogadro's number and the solution's concentration, and the area per molecule is determined. Dividing the circle's area by the square of its radius yields an approximation of pi. The video also discusses the geometry of molecules.

source_title: Exploring the mysteries of the Prime (gaps!) Line.
description: This video explores the distribution of prime numbers using number theory and data visualization. The presenter analyzes gaps between consecutive primes, plotting their frequency against gap size using scatter and log plots. A logarithmic relationship is observed, consistent with the prime number theorem and the work of Hardy and Ramanujan (1917). Further analysis demonstrates arbitrarily large prime gaps, as proven by Ford, Green, Konyagin, and Tao; and Maynard.

source_title: How did the 'impossible' Perfect Bridge Deal happen?
description: This video explores the probability of seemingly improbable events using card games as examples. It applies combinatorial mathematics to calculate the odds of a "perfect bridge deal," comparing them to the odds of other rare events, such as a specific Minecraft event. The video then demonstrates card shuffling techniques and their mathematical basis, concluding that the reported "perfect bridge deal" was likely not a matter of pure chance given the number of possible card arrangements and shuffling methods.

source_title: How does Dobble (Spot It) work?
description: This video explores the mathematical principles underlying the card game Dobble. The game's design, based on finite projective planes, ensures that any two cards share exactly one symbol. Combinatorics and graph theory are used to analyze the optimal number of symbols and cards. A 7x7 grid visualization and a circular arrangement demonstrate the underlying structure. A larger, 10303-card version, "Monomatch: Myriad," is presented, highlighting the extensible nature of the concept.

source_title: How many 3D nets does a 4D hypercube have?
description: This video explores the enumeration of hypercube unfoldings using graph theory and combinatorics. A 3D cube has 11 distinct nets; the presenter demonstrates this by constructing paper models. For higher dimensions, the presenter utilizes tree graphs to represent the hypercube's faces and edges; this approach reveals 261 3D nets for the 4D hypercube. Furthermore, the presenter shows that some of these unfoldings perfectly tile 2D and 3D space. Recent research by Diaz and O’Rourke (2015) and Firschling et al. (2018, 2021) extends this analysis to higher dimensions (5D-10D), revealing a rapidly growing number of unfoldings.

source_title: Why (I thought) the Euro Ball being a Rhombicuboctahedron (would be) good for England.
description: This video explores the geometry of soccer balls. The speaker examines the evolution of designs, from the classic 1970 Adidas design (pentagons and hexagons) to the 2021 Euro ball. Platonic and Archimedean solids are introduced as theoretical frameworks, and the 2021 ball's rhombicuboctahedron design is analyzed. A correlation is presented between the use of rectangular panels and England's success in international finals. A handmade model is used to illustrate the geometrical concepts.

source_title: How do you prove a prime is infinitely fragile?
description: This video explores the concept of “digitally delicate primes,” numbers that lose their prime property when any digit is changed. Building upon Erdős’s 1979 proof of their infinite existence, 2020/21 research by Filaseta and Jillilliart uses covering systems and modular arithmetic to demonstrate that a positive proportion of primes are widely digitally delicate. The Chinese Remainder Theorem facilitates the analysis of arithmetic sequences, revealing additional quantitative insights.

source_title: Why does this balloon have -1 holes?
description: This video explores topological concepts through examples of everyday objects. Using a drinking straw and a pair of trousers, the video demonstrates how stretching and deforming objects, without cutting or joining, can alter their appearance while preserving certain topological properties. The number of holes in these objects is analyzed based on topological rules. Further, the video introduces the concept of manifolds and sub-manifolds, demonstrating how these concepts apply to the surface of a sphere and a torus (donut shape). Finally, Euler characteristics are calculated for spheres and tori using both a traditional definition and an alternative method involving even- and odd-dimensional holes. The video concludes with animations demonstrating the topological transformations discussed.

source_title: How do you prove a prime is infinitely fragile?
description: This video explores the concept of "digitally delicate primes," which are prime numbers that become composite when any digit is altered. Using number theory and a covering system approach, the presenter demonstrates that infinitely many such primes exist, a result proven by P. Erdős and refined by T. Tao. The video concludes by showing how this concept extends to various number bases and uses a visual representation for a clearer explanation.

source_title: Why the longest English word is PAPAL and SPA is the pointiest.
description: This video explores the mathematical properties of word typing on QWERTY keyboards. Using a combination of experimental measurements of key distances (19.05 mm horizontally and vertically) and computational analysis of a 370,103-word dataset, the presenter determines that "minimum" requires the maximum finger travel on a QWERTY keyboard. Furthermore, by applying vector analysis (dot and cross products) and trigonometry, the presenter calculates and ranks words by total travel distance and average angle, revealing “non mischievousness” as the longest word with consistent right turns. The study integrates elements of linguistics, computer science, and mathematics.

source_title: What is the area of a Squircle?
description: This video explores the squircle, a shape between a circle and a square. Using geometric formulas and coordinate systems, the presenter derives equations for squircle area and perimeter. The concept of limits is applied, showing a squircle's transformation as a parameter approaches infinity. The video concludes by introducing the lemniscate and its area calculation involving the arithmetic-geometric mean, connecting geometry, algebra, and statistics.

source_title: Solving the mystery of the impossible cord.
description: This video uses physics and topology to explain how to untangle a cord wrapped around a handle. A mathematical model, involving directional assignments (+1, -1) and net tangle calculations, is presented. Experimental demonstrations illustrate the concept, showcasing the effect of adding a handle and the concept of a Whitehead link in knot theory.

source_title: Why Do Bees Make Rhombic Dodecahedrons?
description: Honeybees utilize hexagons in 2D honeycomb construction for maximal area minimization. However, their 3D structure is a rhombic dodecahedron, not the mathematically optimal Weaire–Phelan structure. Observations of honeycomb construction, coupled with the work of Vincent Galo (Queen Mary University of London), reveal that bees achieve hexagonal patterns through physical pressure, not geometric calculations. This process is analogous to Plateau's laws governing soap film structures.

source_title: Measure the Earth’s Radius! (with this one complicated trick)
description: This video uses geometry to approximate Earth's radius. Inspired by an 11th-century experiment, presenters use the Shard building as a vantage point and a makeshift astrolabe to measure angles to the horizon. Employing trigonometry and the Shard's height, they calculate an approximate radius, ultimately demonstrating the principles of surveying and the historical evolution of measurement techniques.

source_title: Find your own ABC Conjecture Triple
description: This video explores the abc conjecture in mathematics, using visualizations based on number theory and prime factorization. The radical of a number and its quality are defined and demonstrated, utilizing both letter and LEGO blocks for representation. A log-log plot illustrates the conjecture's relationship to a linear distribution. The video also discusses distributed computing and open-source software.

source_title: The Deepest Maths Video Ever [pressure vs depth]
description: This video explores the challenges of precisely measuring the depth of the Mariana Trench using pressure data. Oceanographic data, including pressure, temperature, salinity and sound speed, were collected during a submersible descent. Applying fundamental physics (F=ma, P=F/A) and calculus (integration), a depth of 10,897m was calculated. This differs from the official depth (10,925m) due to confounding factors like water compressibility and varying gravity, as detailed in a NOAA research paper. A final corrected depth of 10,935m (with 95% confidence interval of ±6m) is presented.

source_title: Can you make a hole in a thing bigger than the thing?
description: This video explores the mathematical concept of Rupert polyhedra, focusing on cubes and octahedrons. Using photography, image processing, and 3D printing, the presenter demonstrates the construction of a hole in a cube (or octahedron) large enough for a similarly-sized object to pass through. This is achieved by exploiting the differing cross-sectional areas of these 3D shapes depending on their orientation, drawing on principles of geometry and trigonometry. The Nieuwland constant, representing the maximum scaling ratio, is also discussed.

source_title: The bubble that breaks maths.
description:
This video explores the mathematics of soap films, specifically the shape of a film suspended between two circular hoops. Using calculus and numerical methods (Python code), the presenter derives an equation for the surface area of the film. The optimal shape is shown to be a catenary curve, which is computationally approximated using an iterative process to minimize surface area. Measurements of the hoop diameters and separation, using a tape measure, are compared to those generated by the code; results showed the model's accuracy.
The video also features a hands-on demonstration at Maths City Leeds, UK, showcasing the physics of bubble formation and surface tension.

source_title: Why it’s mathematically impossible to share fair
description: This video explores the apportionment problem in mathematics, specifically the Alabama paradox. Using the 1880 US Census data, the video demonstrates how the number of seats allocated to a state in the House of Representatives can change unexpectedly with the addition of a single seat to the total number of seats. The video compares different apportionment methods—Hamilton, Jefferson, and Adams—highlighting their strengths and weaknesses regarding the quota rule. The presenter shows that the choice of apportionment method and rounding techniques can significantly influence the outcome, potentially leading to counterintuitive results and political disputes. The video concludes by discussing the Huntington-Hill method, currently used by the US Congress, and its complexities.

source_title: Is there an equation for a triangle?
description: This video explores the mathematical representation of shapes using equations. It uses linear equations to generate lines, and introduces absolute value functions to create squares and circles. By employing piecewise functions and the sign function, it demonstrates the creation of triangles, expanding upon standard linear algebra and programming concepts within a visual context. The resulting images include dynamic color gradients and fractal patterns.

source_title: What is the factorial of -½?
description: This video explores the factorial function, using combinatorics to determine the number of ways to shuffle a suit of 13 cards (13!). Extending this to non-integer values requires the Gamma function, plotted as a 3D surface revealing complex number outputs; its real component is visualized, showing "gullies" for negative values, as well as the video's sponsor, KiwiCo.

source_title: Why does the occasional solar eclipse go backwards?
description: This video uses a physical model of the Earth–Moon–Sun system to explain the counter-clockwise orbit of the moon around the Earth when viewed from above the North Pole. This perspective results in a westward-to-eastward shadow transit during eclipses. However, at the South Pole, the shadow appears to move eastward. The presenter’s Antarctic journey and time-and-date.com eclipse viewer illustrate this effect, further explained via a diagram showing Earth's 23.5° axial tilt. This angle influences the location of the tropics and the Antarctic circle, which shrink due to Earth's changing orbit over long timescales. The Earth’s magnetic field, also discussed, is described as more complex and dynamic than the rotational poles.

source_title: My 500-LED xmas tree got into Harvard.
description: This video details the creation of 3D Christmas tree lighting effects. Using 500 LEDs and a Raspberry Pi, the creator initially mapped LED locations via camera-based 3D spatial analysis, applying geometric principles to control lights. Subsequently, a collaboration with Harvard design students improved the system, utilizing geographic information system (GIS) data for more efficient 3D modeling and improved lighting effect deployment, resulting in a more robust and scalable solution. Quantitative analysis of LED spacing (average ~71.6 pixels) provided insights for algorithm optimization.

source_title: The Problem With Infinite Summations On YouTube
description: This video analyzes the financial implications of YouTube Tesla giveaways. Using a diagram and calculations, the presenter demonstrates that recipients are liable for both sales and income taxes, making the gift far less valuable than initially perceived. A mathematical model is then developed to determine the true cost to the giver, incorporating a convergent geometric series. The model clarifies the financial complexities of such promotions, highlighting the importance of accounting and tax considerations.

source_title: The Coupon Collector's Problem (with Geoff Marshall)
description: This video explores the "Park Run Bingo" challenge, a recreational activity involving completing a 5km run and collecting all 60 possible finishing times (seconds). Using statistical analysis, the presenter models this as a coupon collector's problem with replacement, demonstrating that the expected number of trials to complete the challenge is approximately 281. A graph visually displays the nonlinear relationship between runs and unique times achieved. This analysis integrates elements of recreational mathematics, probability, and data visualization.

source_title: Twos-Day Tuesday! 22 YouTubers celebrate all things "two" and nothing goes wrong.
description: This video explores the number two across multiple scientific disciplines. A fundraising effort for WaterAid is described. Number systems (binary) and their applications in engineering (railway counters) are discussed. Mathematical concepts of Mersenne primes and recursive functions are explained through examples. Furthermore, the video touches upon quantum entanglement and its two-state system, as well as evolutionary biology (human vs. chimpanzee chromosomes). Finally, a visual gag using recursive functions to divide a pizza is shown.

source_title: Why don't Jigsaw Puzzles have the correct number of pieces?
description: This video investigates why jigsaw puzzle piece counts are often inaccurate. A 200-piece puzzle is shown to actually contain 204 pieces arranged in a 17x12 grid. The presenter explores the mathematics of aspect ratios and grid ratios, demonstrating discrepancies between advertised and actual piece counts. A Python program, "Jig," is used to calculate optimal grid arrangements for various puzzle sizes, revealing that manufacturers prioritize visually appealing grid ratios over precise piece counts. A collaborative puzzle-solving experiment further illustrates the complexity of matching aspect ratios with integer piece counts.

source_title: Can we calculate 100 digits of π by hand? The William Shanks method.
description: This video documents a Pi Day 2022 event calculating π to 100 digits using Machin's formula. Thirty volunteers, employing a parallel processing approach, computed terms of the formula via hand calculation. Archival research examined original 19th-century manuscripts of similar calculations by William Shanks, revealing a previously unknown error in his work. The experiment also explored the relative frequency of digits in π, and the effectiveness of different calculation methods.

source_title: What was the most expensive book ever?
description: A 1992 book on fruit fly genetics, “The Making of a Fly,” was listed on Amazon for $23,698,655.93. This extreme price resulted from algorithmic interactions between two automated pricing bots. One bot (Bordeebook) increased prices by 27% relative to the competitor, while the other (Profnath) set prices 0.17% below Bordeebook. This dynamic led to exponential price increases until human intervention restored prices to $106.23. The incident highlighted the need for sensible limits in automated pricing systems within complex financial markets.

source_title: How Roman numerals broke the official dog database.
description: This video explores the constraints of the American Kennel Club's dog-naming system. The system uses Roman numerals to distinguish between dogs of the same breed and name, limited to six character spaces. This constraint is analyzed through mathematical principles, demonstrating that the non-positional nature of Roman numerals results in a finite number of possible names (1347). Alternative solutions are presented, offering more expansive naming options by modifying character constraints. The video further promotes a related program from Jane Street.

source_title: I found Amongi in the digits of pi!
description: This video explores the Reddit Place project, a collaborative online canvas where users compete to create images. The presenter analyzes the resulting artwork, focusing on community-driven design and image evolution over time. Mathematical concepts such as the binary expansion of pi and string comparison metrics (Levenshtein distance, Hamming distance) are used to demonstrate how images can be encoded and embedded within numerical sequences. Additionally, the video touches on data visualization and image processing techniques. Finally, the presenter showcases a method for generating prime numbers representing images.

source_title: New World Record! 100 Trillion digits of π.
description: Google Cloud achieved a new record for calculating 100 trillion digits of π using the y-cruncher program and the Chudnovsky algorithm. The computation, which took 157 days, leveraged a n2-highmem-128 Compute Engine node with 128 vCPUs, 864 GB of RAM, and 100 Gbps egress bandwidth. Verification employed the Bailey–Borwein–Plouffe formula. Exponential increases in computational power are shown via a log plot of π digit calculations over time.

source_title: What is wrong with this sine memorisation pattern?
description: This video analyzes a trigonometry meme using mathematical and social science frameworks. The meme presents two tables of sine function values; the second table, though seemingly better organized, lacks mathematical rigor. A unit circle visualization and graphing tool demonstrate the sine wave's continuous nature and the inaccuracy of the meme's simplified presentation. Alternative mnemonic devices using radians and right-angled triangles are introduced.

source_title: The unexpected logic behind rolling multiple dice and picking the highest.
description: Probability distributions for dice rolls in Dungeons & Dragons were analyzed using Python simulations and mathematical models. A simulation of 1,000,000 trials showed that the average outcome of rolling two 20-sided dice and selecting the higher result is approximately 13.8. This result was confirmed by a mathematical model. Additionally, a geometric analysis of 2D and 3D representations of multiple dice rolls revealed patterns related to odd and centered hexagonal numbers. The model also suggests that the average result of rolling *m* *n*-sided dice and picking the highest value approaches *m/(m+1)* *n* as *n* approaches infinity.

source_title: Can you find: five five-letter words with twenty-five unique letters?
description: This video explores the mathematical problem of finding five-letter English words with unique letters. It leverages graph theory to represent words as nodes, connected if they share no letters. The algorithm finds 538 sets of five words fulfilling this criterion, a computation requiring 31.95 days on a standard laptop. A faster solution using graph theory is presented, achieving the same result in 22 minutes. The video compares computational approaches and discusses algorithm efficiency.

source_title: Can you trust an elegant conjecture?
description: This video explores the Look and Say sequence in mathematics. The presenter introduces the sequence and challenges viewers to find the next term. The concept is then extended to a binary representation, analyzed experimentally by calculating the ratio of 0s to 1s in each term. The ratio approaches 1.6657… as the sequence progresses. Utilizing linear algebra, the presenter demonstrates how eigenvector analysis reveals this ratio, providing a concise method for calculating the long-term behavior of the sequence. The video also touches upon applications in quantum information theory.

source_title: Someone improved my code by 40,832,277,770%
description: This video explores the computational complexity of finding word sets with no common letters. Initial Python code took 32 days. Optimized Python code (using graph theory) reduced runtime to 15 minutes. Further improvements in Java and C achieved runtimes of 15 seconds and 2.58 seconds, respectively. Utilizing bitwise operations in C++ resulted in a runtime of 0.006761 seconds, representing over 800 million times faster execution than the initial Python implementation. A survey of code optimization techniques revealed the use of graph theory, parallelization, and bitwise operations as key performance enhancers. A new solution employing bitwise operations was also identified, highlighting the ongoing evolution of code optimization.

source_title: I Found a Whale Using Maths!
description:
A new convolutional neural network algorithm identifies individual humpback whales (Megaptera novaeangliae) from fluke photographs. A densely connected convolutional network (DenseNet) extracts keypoints; a separate DenseNet compares these against a database. The algorithm achieves 97.1% accuracy, reducing error rates from 6–9% to 1–3% and near-zero for high-quality images; time savings exceed 98%.
This work integrates zoology, computer vision, and machine learning.

source_title: An infinite number of $1 bills and an infinite number of $20 bills would be worth the same
description: This video explores the mathematical concept of infinity through the lens of a viral meme. The meme asserts that infinite quantities of $1 and $20 bills hold equal value, a proposition analyzed using set theory. The video leverages analogy and visual demonstrations to explain the counterintuitive nature of infinite sets, contrasting the meme's flawed logic with the concept of cardinality. It references a related video on counting past infinity, highlighting the concept of different sized infinities.

source_title: Can the Same Net Fold into Two Shapes?
description: This video explores the mathematical concept of nets, specifically focusing on the number of distinct orthogonal nets that fold into the same cuboid. The presenter demonstrates, via paper-cutting and folding, that a single net can produce multiple cuboids with equal surface area. This is supported by data from a 2007 book on geometric folding algorithms, and further explored with a 3D plot of possible cuboids. A 2015 paper shows an example of a net forming three incongruent cuboids, prompting the presenter to create and show physical models. The video concludes by highlighting the ongoing research into the limits of this problem and the potential for more complex solutions.

source_title: Making efficient Platonic and Archimedean shapes in a kaleidoscope
description: This video explores the mathematical principles underlying kaleidoscopic geometry. Using physical models and mirrors, the presenter demonstrates how portions of a cube can create the illusion of a whole cube through reflection. Further, the video discusses the construction of kaleidoscopes to generate rhombic dodecahedra and other shapes, integrating concepts from geometry, optics, and art. A total of nine planes of reflection are identified for a cube. A novel design using two-way mirrors is also proposed.

source_title: Once a Millennium Alignment of All Three Norths
description: This video explores the convergence of true north, magnetic north, and grid north in the UK. The presenter uses map navigation and compass readings to illustrate the concepts of geodesy and geomagnetism. A spherical model demonstrates how map projections (cartography) affect grid north, while a compass shows the dynamic nature of magnetic north. The video concludes by showing how these three 'norths' converge at a specific point in the UK, and that this point shifts over time, with a deviation of up to 19% in the north.

source_title: The Genius Geometry of the James Webb Space Telescope
description: This video uses a scale model of the James Webb Space Telescope's primary mirror to explain the differences between images from the James Webb and Hubble Space Telescopes.
